“Very simple Miniatures rules. Ranges, distances, and movement abstracted. No record keeping, charts, or tables. Games resolved in under 10 minutes. These rules are based on Sci-Fi figures, but other types will work just as well.”

A miniatures game to be played with ten to twenty figures, or more. The players divide the figures into two opposing forces “based on aesthetic reasons.” Combat is resolved starting with weapons that can attack at extreme range, followed in succession by long range attacks, medium range attacks, short range attacks, and finally hand-to-hand attacks. A single six-sided die roll is used to resolve combat.

38110.name: Quidditch Cup
38110.description:
“Card game for 2 players. Players are each in control of opposing Quidditch teams.” Based on the magical sport from the world of Harry Potter.

In each Action Phase, the players make three piles of face-down cards which are later revealed simultaneously: the Bludger-Beater Pile, Quaffle-Chaser Pile, and Snitch-Seeker Pile.

To win the game, a player must have a specified force value in the Snitch-Seeker Pile, together with at least one Snitch and one Seeker Card. This causes the player to score 150 points and the game is over.

38111.name: Raging Gun Battle
38111.description:
“Each player controls one character in a Raging Gun Battle.” The object of the game is to reduce all of your opponents to zero Hit Points.

The players pick one of the following “Character Archetypes”: Bruiser, Thug, Fem Fatale, Secret Agent, Mercenary, Black Ops Specialist, Hard-Boiled Cop, Enforcer, Hit-man, Rookie Cop, Assassin, Crime Boss, Gangster, Gun Nut, etc.

Each Character starts with ten Hit Points, one Gun Card, and two rolls on the Ability table. The abilities a character may have are: Tough, Danger Sense, Armed to the Teeth, Smart, Fast, Stealth, Resourceful, Lucky, Tactics, and Sharpshooter.

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. There are seven types of cards in the deck: Gun, Damage, Bullets, Card play, Attack Advantage, Negate Attack, and Extra Attack.

38112.name: Ragnarok
38112.description:
"The last epic battle in Norse mythology of Good against Evil."

The forces of the Good Aesir and Vanir battle against the Evil Giants. In addition to ten Norse Gods, the forces of Good are supported by Valkyries, Einheriar, Dwarves, and Elves. The forces of Evil are supported by Undead Hordes, Stone Giants, Storm Giants, Fire Giants, and Frost Giants. Each unit is rated for movement, strength, range, and any special abilities.

The game is played on a hex mapsheet depicting Asgard. The invading Giants line up on one side of the map. The forces of Good begin clustered around Valhalla. The object of the game is to destroy all opposing units.

38113.name: Rappa Nui
38113.description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Easter Island Theme. Players control rival tribes trying to build the most and biggest Moai.”

The card deck contains seven suits of cards. Four suits are Resource Cards: Food, Wood, People, and Stone. Three suits are Event Cards: Raids, Huri Moai, and Disasters. The players form melds of Resource Cards to earn Moai Tokens.

The game ends when the players have gone through the deck three times. The player with the most Moai Tokens at the end of the game wins.

38114.name: Ravenloft Quest
38114.description:
“Each player controls a party of Heroes traveling through the Northern Core of Ravenloft, the Demi-Plane of Dread.”

The game is played on a track ninety spaces long. The start and end spaces are Mist spaces, the other spaces are Domain spaces. Each named Domain is eight spaces long. There are eleven Domains, each of which has its own encounter table.

“The first player whose party (pawn) reaches the end space wins. You lose if all of your Heroes are killed.”

This is a fan-made game available at http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/RLQ.html

38115.name: Redwall
38115.description:
“Two Player Card Game. Based on the Book ‘Redwall’ by Brian Jacques”

“One Player represents Matthias the Mouse and the Defenders of Redwall Abbey. The other Player represents Cluny the Scourge and his Army of Rats.”

“Victory: Whichever player wins the Final Battle wins the game. The Final Battle is hand #13. If the Cluny player wins 3 hands in a row, the next hand is automatically the Final Battle.”

38116.name: Regiments & Roundshot
38116.description:
"Simple Napoleonic Miniatures Rules System. Uses Dry Erase Board, Markers, Dice, Risk Figures, and Regular Playing cards."

Scale: Each figure represents an infantry battalion, cavalry regiment, or artillery division. Each inch equals one half mile. One turn equals one half hour.

The game is played on a white dry-erase board. Terrain features are drawn directly on the board: "Green Patches for Woods. Blue for Water. Red Lines for Roads. Black Dots for Hamlets and Important Buildings. Irregular shaded areas for larger Urban Areas. Black Lines for Walls & Fortifications. Brown dotted lines for Hills."

"Use plastic figures from a Risk Game. This will include: Infantry, Cavalry, and Artillery. Each player also needs an HQ figure to represent the General."

38117.name: Renaissance Fair
38117.description:
"Get the most out of your trip to the Renaissance festival. Board game for 2+ players."

The game is played on an 85 space track. Each space is named for an event, activity, or exhibition. Examples include Glass Blower, Throwing Axes, Medieval Beer, Henna Tattoos, and Tarot Reader. Tokens are gained by landing on certain spaces.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get five of each type of Token: Craft, Game, Food, Acting, Music, and Education.

38118.name: Revolution
38118.description:
“Card Game. Simulates a Coup in a Developing Country. One player is the Government. The other is the Rebels.”

The game uses a deck of 140 cards. There are three types of cards in the deck – Unit, Dummy, and Modifier. Each card has a Force value, from zero (Dummy) to twelve.

The players draw hands of ten cards and fight a series of battles between units. This process repeats each turn. The game ends when one player has no units remaining, in which case the other player wins.

38119.name: Rules of Order
38119.description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Representation of a parliamentary debate. Based on Robert’s Rules of Order. Players compete to capture the Floor, which enables them to use up (gain) the most Time.”

“Victory: The player with the most Time Chips at the end of the game wins.”

38120.name: Rum Runner
38120.description:
“2-Player Pirate Strategy War Game. One player plays the rum runners. The other player plays the interceptors (rival pirates).”

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. There are seven types of units in the game: Swashbucklers, Swordsman, Slashers, Rum Runners, Musketeers, Pirates, and Mercenaries. The Rum Runner player has three Rum Runners, three Pirates, two Musketeers, and two Mercenaries. The Interceptor player has six Swordsmen, three Slashers, and one Swashbuckler. The Rum Runner player must get one Rum Runner to the opposite side of the board to win. The Interceptor must kill all of the Rum Rummer units.

The designer notes: “Game was originally designed to be played with the 37 piece plastic ‘Pirates on the High Seas’ set from D&D Distributing Inc. but is suitable for use with paper tiles.”

38121.name: Sailor Moon
38121.description:
"Help Sailor Moon & the Sailor Scouts protect Earth from the Negaverse and the Negamoon."

Each player has a custom deck of sixty cards. One player uses the Space Scouts Deck, the other player controls the Nega Deck. Alternate sets of cards for the Nega Deck are used to reflect the events of season one (Negaverse) and season two (Negamoon).

The first player to win three hands wins the game.

38122.name: Shot, Shell & Grape
38122.description:
"Two player Card game depicting Napoleonic era warfare."

The game uses two card decks, the Battalion Deck and the Tactics Deck. The Tactics deck is composed of maneuvers, formations, weapons, incidents, and terrain types. The Battalion Deck consists of thirty three types of military units (Infantry, Cavalry, and Artillery).

Cards are played on the table in battlefield positions representing the Left Flank, Left Center, Center, Right Center, and Right Flank positions. The first player to be routed from three of the five forward positions loses the game.

These rules served as the basis for the game Ready Aim Fire.

38123.name: Space Opera
38123.description:
"Explore the mysteries of outer space with your trusty ship and intrepid crew."

The player is in command of a starship. The attributes of the starship and the skills of the crew are randomly determined by rolling on tables. The six member crew includes a captain, science officer, chief engineer, and three specialists (science, technical, or ship systems). The object of the game is to complete ten missions in the shortest time possible.

Missions are randomly generated by referring to tables. To complete a mission, the ship must face three random threats generated by rolling on tables. The crew and ship must have the skills and systems required by the threats and the mission to successfully complete the mission. If the player cannot complete the mission, the result is randomly determined by rolling on the failure table.

The game also includes three additional scenarios that expand on the basic game.

In the Drax Campaign scenario, the player must complete missions in order to win the war against the Drax. The player controls three starships. The attributes for these ships are generated by rolling on special wartime ship systems tables. Successfully completing missions makes a player victory more likely, while the failure to complete missions will lead to a Drax victory.

In the scenario A Long Way Home the starship must complete missions to reach a home destination. In the scenario A Campaign of Terror the starship must complete missions to defeat aliens threatening the human colonies.

38124.name: Starmageddon
38124.description:
A simple game of tactical spaceship combat.

Eleven types of ships are presented in the game. Each ship is rated for movement, hits, and the number of weapons systems carried. Seventeen different weapons are available, each rated for size, damage, range, and ammunition supply. Defensive systems which may be installed on ships include armor, missile defense system, and a self-destruct mechanism.

The players build fleets of ships which have an equal number of hit points, as set by scenario.

38125.name: Sin City
38125.description:
“Card game based on the Frank Miller Comic Sin City. 2+ Players.”

The game uses a custom deck composed of Event Cards and seven types of Character Cards: Event, Criminal, Agent, Psychopath, Hero, Victim, and Crime Boss. Each Character has a Fight rating and a Sin rating.

The players draw Character cards, place them into play, and use them to hunt down and kill the Characters of the opposing players. Sin Points are earned by killing Characters. The amount received depends on the types of Characters involved.

“Victory: The first player to accumulate 100 Sin Points is the winner.”

38126.name: Ski Race
38126.description:
“Card and Board game for 2-4+ players. Alpine Ski Race theme.”

The game is played on a track 100 spaces long. The first space is the starting gate and the last space is the finish line. Each space is randomly assigned a number from 1 to 10. A standard deck of cards is used to govern movement of the ski racers.

“Victory: First player to reach the Finish line is the winner.”

38127.name: Sleep
38127.description:
“Card Game 2+ players. Players are trying to see who can get the best nights rest.”

Each player uses a Sleep Track marked with five stages ranging from Awake (stage 0) to Slow Wave Sleep (stage 4) to show which Sleep Stage the player is on. The players play Sleep Cards to advance to deeper levels of sleep. Wake Cards are played on an opponent to reduce the opponent’s Sleep Stage. At the end of each turn, a player gains a number of Sleep Tokens equal to the player’s current Sleep Stage.

“The game lasts 16 turns. Each turn represents Half an Hour. This would correspond to a full nights sleep of 8 hours.” The winner is the player with the most Sleep Tokens at the end of the game.

38128.name: Scooby Doo Mystery Game
38128.description:
“Solve Mysteries with Scooby Doo & the gang of Mystery Inc. Card game for 2+ players.”

The players attempt to solve Mysteries by playing melds. A Mystery is solved by playing a meld containing one of each of the following types of cards: Scooby, Shaggy, Fred, Velma, Daphne, Villain, and Location.

“Winning: The first player to solve 3 Mysteries is the winner.”

38129.name: Sea Intercept
38129.description:
“Card game for 2 players. Modern Naval Warfare Theme.”

The card deck contains four types of cards: Unit, Detect, Attack, and Counter. Units Cards are deployed as part of a player’s forces and remain in play until the end of the game unless destroyed. Detect Cards and Attack Cards are used to make attacks against enemy units. Counter Cards are used to counter attacks.

“The game ends when a player goes to draw a card, and there are no cards left in the deck. The player with the most deployed units at the end of the game wins.”

38130.name: Search for El Dorado
38130.description:
A card game for two or more players based on the Search for El Dorado, the legendary lost city of gold.
The players form Expeditions by playing three card melds (one Leader, one Follower, and one Motivation). Each Expedition a player has in play attempts to make discoveries. Each Discovery Card gained by an Expedition is rated at one or two Discovery Points.

The game ends when the deck has been gone through twice. The player with the most Discovery Points at the end of the game wins.

38131.name: Solar Racers
38131.description:
A space race card game for two or more players. Each player controls a space ship. The first ship to travel 100 Astronomical Units wins the game.

The game uses a deck of sixty-five cards. There are four types of cards in the deck: Propulsion, Difficulty, Breakdown, and Repairs. Players advance by playing Propulsion Cards. Difficulty Cards can be played to negate specific Propulsion Cards. Breakdown Cards can be played on opposing players. A Breakdown Card stays in effect until it is repaired with the appropriate Repair Card.

38132.description:
“Welcome knave! The premise of Sorcery Chess is that the king is also a powerful wizard.”

The game is played using a standard chess set. However, the normal rules of Chess are altered by the use of spells by the Wizard Kings.

At the end of each player’s turn, the player rolls on a Spell Table and records the spell in a Spell Book. A player may only retain five spells at a time. Each turn a player may choose to move normally or to cast a spell. Most spells modify the way a piece can move. The rules also provide for Artifacts, which are like permanent spells, and Events, which occur immediately upon being rolled.

Expands:

Chess
38132.name: Sorcery Chess

38133.name: Space Base
38133.description:
“Players control rival commercial colonies on a small piece of stable crust on a volcanic moon.” Watch out for the random meteor strikes!

The game is played on a 10x10 grid with spaces large enough to hold one game card. Each player starts out with one Outpost located in a corner of the map. The deck of 120 cards contains a variety of installations, resources, and volcanic sites. The players earn income from installations. Some installations are required to be adjacent to a certain site or sites in order to produce income.

“The game ends when the last card is drawn from the deck. The player with the most credits at the end of the game is the winner.”

38134.name: Space Blast
38134.description:
“Backgammon variant on a circular board with cards and a sci-fi theme. One player is the Terran Defense Force. The other player is the Evil Empire.”

The board is a circular track divided into twenty-eight spaces. There are four planet spaces equally spaced around the board. Each side has fifteen units marked with a force value from one to five. Cards can modify combat or provide a variety of other effects. The first player to occupy all four planet spaces is the winner.

38135.name: Space Program
38135.description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Each player represents a National Space Program. Players acquire technologies, perform Missions, and develop Space Industries.”

The deck contains eight types of cards: Projects, Missions, Industry, Lift Capability, Near Earth, Zero-G Industries, Stellar Transport, and Disasters. Each type of card has a Prestige Point value.

Each turn represents a decade. The game ends when the players have gone through the deck twice. The player with the most Prestige Points at the end of the game wins.

38136.name: Space Station Alpha
38136.description:
“Bidding & Placement Game. Each player represents a space agency: NASA, European Union, Russia, Japan, etc. Players are working together to build the ISS (International Space Station). Players add Modules and score points.”

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. The center four spaces of the board represent the Core Command and Control Module of the space station.

The space station is to be constructed out of sixty Modules represented by cardboard counters. There are four each of fifteen different types of Modules in the counter mix. Each player has a set of forty markers in a unique color that are used to show ownership of Modules placed on the space station. Victory points are earned based on various factors related to the placement and location of Modules.

“Objective: The game ends at the end of the turn when all 60 modules have been placed. The player with the most victory points at the end of the game wins.”

38137.name: Spectrum
38137.description:
A card game based on the colors produced when white light is divided by a prism.

The deck of fifty-two cards includes seven cards of the following colors: Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Indigo, and Violet. There are seven cards in each suit. There are also two wild cards (Infra-Red and Ultra-Violet) and a Prism card.

The object of the game is to be the first player to play a combo. The combos that may be played involve cards of the same color or cards in spectrum order.

38138.name: Spelljammer

boardgamefamily.7757: From RPG books to board games

38138.description:
“Battle between Good & Evil in the SpellJammer Universe. Based on the AD&D RPG by TSR. Card game for 2+ players.” The players form fleets of ships and attempt to control Locales.

Each player must play as good or evil. They players use a deck containing eight types of cards: Locales, Ships, Monsters, Equipment, Crew, Characters, Events, and Combat.

The winner is the player who controls the most Locales when the deck runs out.

38139.name: Spider-Man
38139.description:
“2 player card game. One player is Spiderman (Spidey). The other player is the Bad Guys.” Each player uses a unique card deck.

The players bet Plot Tokens which go to the player having the higher ranking hand. In the case of a tie, the wagered tokens carry over to the next hand

The object of the game is to acquire all 50 Plot Tokens. Each player starts with 25 Plot Tokens.

38140.description:
A game played on a standard chess board. Each player has one king piece and thirty-one flat, stackable pieces.

The movement of the stackable pieces varies based on how many pieces are in the stack, from one to five. Landing on a stack captures the whole stack.

The object of the game is to capture the opponent’s king.
38140.name: Stakk Chess

38141.description:
Bitwy II wojny światowej (B-35) (Battles of World War II) is a system designed for representing World War II medium battles.

Counters represent battalions and companies, one hex represents about 2000m (depending on specific game), one turn represents 8, 12 or 24 hours.

B-35 has a high level of complexity. Rules include airborne/sea landings, fire combat (long distance combat between armoured units), air force, engineers, special units etc.
Another distinctive feature of this system is the way of determining strength of unit. Each unit has a chart with its strength; when unit suffers loses, player has to mark it on chart.
Classical activation system ("I go, you go") and simplified command rules drives the game.

The game contains fiction map and scenarios but historical units (German, American, Polish and British).
38141.name: Bitwy II wojny światowej

38142.name: Star Craft Spawn
38142.description:
“Two player card game set in the StarCraft universe.” Inspired by the popular computer game.

Each player gets a unique deck – the Terran Deck or the Zerg Deck. The decks include eight types of cards: Spacecraft, Infantry, Vehicle, Hero, Building, Faction, Advance, and Event. Both players start with a hand of five cards and their Command Structure deployed.

Each turn a player may deploy cards. Deployed Units (Spacecraft, Infantry, Vehicle, and Hero Cards) may be used to attack opposing Units or Buildings. The object of the game is to destroy your opponent’s Command Structure, represented by a Building Card.

38143.name: Pink Pebbles
38143.description:
From the box:

A game about how money began.

Pink Pebbles takes players back to a world without money. Players begin as primitive farmers, trying to produce everything they need.

But there's an entrepreneur in every crowd - and some of the players soon begin to barter, trying to swap extra things they've made. The successful players become specialists and store owners. That's where the pink pebbles come in. Any good store needs some form of money....

The player who has the most pink pebbles with at least two stores at the end of the game wins.

38144.name: Game of Oil
38144.description:
This exclusively equipped pre-war boardgame simulates the exploration of oil fields and the drilling for oil.

As the box lid says: Suspense - Exitement - Speculation !!!

The contents are a lot of drilling rigs, oil tanks and game pawns, all made of wood in 7 different colours. Add a lot of company shares and money chips made of thick cardboard and you have a heavy game !

Gameplay was really good for its time, it's driven by an extremely large spinner (10 x 10 inches with 32 segments)and the amount of risk the players may take in drilling and how much shares they deal out to minimize their losses but on the other side also their wins.
It's up to your feeling to find a good balance for all this !

38145.name: Monopoly: Den Haag
38145.description:
The classic game of Monopoly, with a theme from the city of Den Haag in the Netherlands. Every street has a name from the city, and added to that has banners/commercials from companies in that neighborhood.

This is an authorized edition.

38146.name: Trucopoly
38146.description:
From the publisher:

Its all about the trucking business, You know those BIG TRUCKS that are always flying down the road. The object of the game is, who ever builds a fleet of ten trucks first wins. As you build your fleet of trucks, you contend with WEIGH STATIONS, DOT CHECKS, IRS, FUEL TAX, ROAD TAX, SHIPPERS, BROKERS TRUCK STOPS AND THE LIST GOES ON. Unlike some game's where every one gets tired and quits, this game is fast, fun and keeps you thinking. Someone will build a fleet of trucks and win the game in a fair amount of time. If you are wondering, yes there are forty trucks in the game to support up to 4 players.

38147.name: Beat the Cops
38147.description: The object of the game is to be the last player remaining, or the player with the most money after the agreed upon time limit. Players take turns venturing out from their homes driving around trying to make money while evading the cops that are always chasing them. Most of the game is spent avoiding fines and arrest from the cops.

38148.name: Osmosis
38148.description:
"Osmosis" was published in A Gamut of Games. A word from Sid Sackson:
"It would be difficult for me to say why, how, or even when I created the following work. Like the game itself, the ideas seemed to flow shapelessly around until, before I realized it, they had taken concrete shape.
"Osmosis is a subtle game. What constitutes a good hand? What constitutes a good play? The contestants must discover this for themselves, more by intuition than by logic"

Osmosis is played with a normal deck of cards, but without some cards according to the number of players. Each player starts with a eight card hand and to win a round he must gather more than 11 cards, when he scores alone or he loses when he reaches 4 cards, then all other players scores. Cards are gathered by trading with the other player is very specific ways.

38149.name: Patterns
38149.description:
"Patterns" was published in A Gamut of Games. A word by Sid Sackson:
"Patterns has many characteristics of a board game. All the cards are face up on the table, so there are no mysteries. Play is in moves, which are determined by the relationship of the cards to one another. Some players find the interplay of the "patterns" a fascinating challenge. Other never see it. To find out whether it is "your cup of tea" you'll have to try it."

Each player takes twelve cards from a normal deck of cards numbered from 1 to 13 (Ace to K). Then shuffles his cards and deals then in two lines of six cards each. The objective is, by moving two cards each turn, complete a pattern before the other player. The catch is that the moves you are allowed to make are based on your opponents' cards. If you do a difficult move, you win points, if you make an easy one you lose points. When you win a hand, you score the number of point you get that hand (can be zero).

38150.name: All My Diamonds
38150.description:
"All my Diamonds" was published in A Gamut of Games, words from Sid Sackson:
"All my Diamonds" is a game I conceive as a change of pace from Poker. Although there is no similarity in the play, it satisfies the same urge for speculation. It is, basically an auction game where players must decide whether they can earn more by buying or by selling"

All my Diamonds is played with a regular deck of cards with the "10" out, making 48 cards. Cards are divided in sets, with each card belonging a "value" set and also to a "suit" set, each set has 12 cards and players must set collections of 10 cards in any set to win a hand. Players exchange cards by auctioning all cards in a set in their hands.

The player with most points win in the end, this can be achieved by completing the sets, that once completed are exchanged for points, or by selling his cards on the auction.

38151.name: Rusted Heroes
38151.description:
"The King has vanished and the kingdom has plunged into chaos, heirs to the throne are divided, and invaders have landed on the shores, plundering the land. Choose a faction and rally your War Band to fight for glory and honor. Become a Rusted Hero today!"

Rusted Heroes 32mm Table-top Miniature Game is a fast playing skirmish style combat game system using d10s (1 to 10+) not percentage dice. The higher the roll the better in most cases. Each miniature represents a character on the battlefield. Since this is a skirmish based game each side will have any where from five or more miniatures in their War Band.

Each character has two actions per turn. With these two Actions a character can do several things on their turn. Some may include a standard move and attack, use both actions to make a run movement, attack an enemy model twice, attack once and reserve one for defense, open a door or portcullis, change weapons from a bow to a sword, etc...

38152.name: Pass the Buck
38152.description:
Pass the Buck is one of at least three in this company's series of nature themed "Cigar Box" games. Pass the Buck is themed around North American wildlife, in particular 15 different animals on the cards from eagle, dove, cardinal, buck, skunk, bear, etc. in beautifully engraved animal art.

Object: 4-10 players vie to be the last player holding 1 or more wooden nickels.

Components:
-Cigar Box decorated with a deer Buck and red scroll with game title all in 18th century style drawn art. Interestingly, game is sealed with a simulated "tax stamp" featuring the serial number and company logo.
-52 playing cards in 4 sets of 10 (each set features 10 different birds), and 12 special play cards (4 bear, 2 duck, 1 doe, 1 skunk) with variable special abilities.
-50 wooden nickels with company logo on one side, and game title and image of Buck on the other.

Game Play description:
Each player starts with 5 wooden nickels. The dealer deals each player 1 card. In turn, each player looks secretly at the card and decides whether to keep or trade with player on the left. A player is stuck with their choice (keep or trade) once completed. Since players want the lowest value card possible, this adds an element of risk assessment, as the player(s) with the highest value must pay a nickel into the pot. Last player standing with nickels, after others are bankrupt wins. Special play cards change order and value of play for more variability to play.

38154.name: Electronic Pictionary Man
38154.description: This variation of Pictionary revolves around a battery powered plastic figure. A look at the sole of the figure's foot reveals the target word that one has to convey to one's teammates. The player may use a marker to draw on the figure or use the figure as a prop to elicit the winning word. The figure has a built in timer and over two thousand words in its memory.

38156.name: Columbus!
38156.description:
Players buy and sell five different commodities until they think that they have enough to sail from Spain to claim settlements around the Caribbean. Fortifications cost money but unfortified settlements can be captured by other players.

[from the box top] Explore and conquer the New World: force the other players out of the game through trading and selling commodities, trading commodities for outposts, collecting tributes, and challenging other players for outposts.

38157.name: Wizards
38157.description:
“Two-player Card game based on the animated film WIZARDS by Ralph Bakshi. One player is the good Wizard Avatar. The other player is his evil brother Blackwolf. Both battle for world domination. On Avatar’s side is Magic, Elven Races, and Faerie Folk. Blackwolf's armies are filled with Mutants, Demons, and Ancient Technologies.”

Each player uses a separate custom card deck composed of the following types of cards: Leader, Knowledge, Armies, Place, Event, Technology, Strategy, Resources, and Morale. In addition, the Avatar Deck includes Magic Cards. Each hand the players seek to play cards having the highest total in Power points. The winner of a hand receives a Victory Token. The first player to acquire seven Victory Tokens wins the game.

38158.name: Naughty & Nice
38158.description:
Naughty & Nice is a quick playing card game I made for a friend's 30th birthday. During the game you play cards on yourself and on other players to increase or decrease your Naughty and Nice ratings. The object of the game is to end with the highest Naughty and Nice ratings with the smallest difference between them.

There are also Shiny! cards. You can play Shiny! cards to take cards from other players. At the end of the game, each Shiny! card has a 50/50 chance of being worth points. If a Shiny! card is worth points, you can add it to your Naughty score or your Nice score.

Naughty & Nice is a game for two to four players. It uses a custom card deck and a single die. A four-player game takes about 30 minutes to play. While the gameplay is rather simple, the ever-so-slightly mature theme of the game makes Naughty & Nice appropriate for Ages 16 and up.

boardgamehonor.8417: 2009 Golden Geek Best Party Board Game Nominee

38159.description:
Your quiet little 16th century village has suddenly become infested with some very unfriendly werewolves...can you and the other villagers find them before they devour everyone?

Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition is the ultimate party game for anywhere from 5 to 68 players of all ages. Each player has an agenda: as a villager, hunt down the werewolves; as a werewolf, convince the other villagers that you're innocent, while secretly dining on those same villagers each night. Dozens of special roles are available to help both the villagers and the werewolves achieve their goals while thwarting their opponents.

Contents More than 30 unique roles, 18 different scenarios to allow groups of all sizes and experience levels to quickly get up and running, a set of 80 fully illustrated cards, a moderator scorepad to keep track of games, and a comprehensive game guide with dozens of pages full of insights, tips and strategies. This set has everything you need for the best Ultimate Werewolf experience possible, whether you’re playing with a small circle of friends at home, a huge gathering of gamers in Ohio or as an engaging team building exercise at the office.

Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition Roles:
Apprentice Seer, Aura Seer, Bodyguard, Cupid, Diseased, Ghost, Hunter, Idiot, Lycan, Magician, Martyr, Mason (3), Mayor, Old Hag, Old Man, P.I., Pacifist, Priest, Prince, Seer (2: 1 male & 1 female), Spellcaster, Tough Guy, Troublemaker, Villager (20), Witch, Sorcerer, Minion, Werewolf (12), Wolf Cub, Cursed, Doppelganger, Drunk, Cult Leader, Hoodlum, Tanner, Teenage Werewolf, Lone Wolf, Vampire (6), Amulet of Protection, Moderator, Blank Cards (3)

Re-implements:

Werewolf
Ultimate Werewolf: Whitebox Edition




Differences between 2010 Edition and 2008 Edition:

Role cards now have ability text
Includes Ultimate Werewolf: Classic Movie Monsters
No Magician card
Only eight Werewolf cards (note that rulebook still says twelve)
Only two blank cards (note that rulebook still says three)
Vampires are valued at -7 (previously -8)




Differences between 2011 Edition and 2010 Edition:

Includes Ultimate Werewolf: Night Terrors instead of Ultimate Werewolf: Classic Movie Monsters




Differences between 2013 Edition and 2011 Edition:

Includes Ultimate Werewolf: Urban Legends instead of Ultimate Werewolf: Night Terrors
38159.name: Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition

38160.description:
"One player takes the side of the Atlanteans. The other player takes command of the combined Armies of the Five Foes of Atlantis."

The game is played on a hex map. The continent of Atlantism containing the main city of Atlantis, is at the center of the map, surrounded by water. A thin border of land around the outer edges of the map represents the homelands of the enemies: The Barbarians, Greeks, Egyptians, Africans, and Lemurians.

Each enemy has a unique set of forces. Units are rated for power and movement. Some units are amphibious, some cannot leave the water, and others may fly. Mage and Priest units have magic powers.

"Victory: The Atlanteans are victorious if they destroy their enemies completely. The Five Foes win if they destroy all the Atlanteans or a have a spellcaster cast the cataclysm spell in the Temple of Posideon. The Atlanteans win a minor victory if there is no winner after 20 turns."
38160.name: War for Atlantis

38161.name: War in Hell
38161.description:
"2 Player Card game. Diabolic Fantasy theme. The Arch Devils Intrigue and do battle to control the 9 Planes of Hell. Each player controls a Faction of Arch Devils."

The object of the game is to control all Nine Planes of Hell. The players use the various units (Arch Devils, Dukes of Hell, Greater Devils, and Lesser Devils) to fight for control. Event Cards can be used to give advantages in battle.

38162.name: Third World
38162.description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Simulation of problems facing third world countries. Each player controls his own Third World country."

The deck includes six types of cards: Political Reforms, Economic Reforms, Ecological Reforms, Political Crises, Economic Crises, and Ecological Crises.

Each player has three statistics that are tracked during the game: Political Stability, Economic Stability, and Ecological Stability. Each category starts with a value of 20.

A value of zero or less in Political Stability represents Anarchy & Civil War. Zero or less in Economic Stability represents Economic Collapse, and zero or less in Ecological Stability represents an Ecological Disaster.

A player wins by achieving a score of 30 or more in all three categories.

38163.name: Wizards & Warlords
38163.description:
A game of fantasy warfare between the forces of competing warlords.

The game is played on an area mapsheet. Three types of special territories are marked on the board: water areas, barren areas, and strongholds. Each stronghold is identified with one of the warring factions: Dwarf, Kobold, Goblin, Hobgoblin, Orc, Shaman, Elf, Halfling, Illusionist, Fey, Gnome, Artificer, Necromancer, Vampire, Knight, etc. Each of the factions has an associated warlord which a player may choose to play.

"Tokens represent an abstract combination of military, tactical, and magical strength at your disposal. The identity of a stronghold determines what type of token it produces. For example, a Dwarf stronghold produces dwarf tokens. In battle a dwarf token allows one roll on the dwarf warlord table."

"The objective is to destroy your opponents Warlord token and capture all of your opponents strongholds."

38164.name: Time Bandits
38164.description:
"Card game based on the Terry Gilliam Movie. Each player controls a group of diminutive individuals in possession of a stolen Map of all Time & Space. Players race to steal the most treasure from History."

"Each player is represented by an abstract group of Time Bandits of Uncertain number. In addition to these abstract individuals, players will recruit Character cards. Character cards represent more concrete individuals with special abilities."

The players travel between the Time of Legends and various historical periods represented by Location Cards. Each time a player travels to a new Location, the player may steal a Treasure. Danger cards (Foe, Delay, or God) may be played on other players to hamper their efforts.

"The game ends when a turn starts with no cards left in the deck. The player with the most Treasure cards at the end of the game wins. If tied the player with the most characters wins. If still tied, the shortest player wins."

38165.name: Water Gun Fight
38165.description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Each player controls a group of Kids with Water guns.” The winner is the first player to soak ten opposing kids.

The card deck includes twenty-three different types of water guns, each rated for Volume (amount of water expended per attack) and Capacity (amount of water held). There are also cards for each type of Kid, rated for Hits (amount of water required to soak) and any special advantages. There are also Modifier and Event Cards which can offer assistance in attack or defense.

In addition to the arsenal of water guns, the players may also be able to obtain Water Balloon tokens during the game. A six-sided die is used to resolve Water Balloon and Water Gun combat.

38166.name: Thundercats
38166.description:
A card game inspired by the animated television series of the same name.

One player uses the Thunder Cat deck and the other player uses the Evil Mutant deck. Opposing Character cards battle it out each hand, supported by Weapon, Companion, and Vehicle Cards. The player whose cards have the highest total Force value wins the hand.

The first player to win five hands wins the game.

38167.name: Viking Raid
38167.description:
"Card game for 2-4+ Vikings ... The most Scandinavian player goes first."

Players build a ship, give it a crew, and set out for a destination. Along the way encounters are faced. At the destination, the Vikings must battle the local inhabitants. Defeat the locals, pillage, plunder, and return home - all in a days work for Viking raiders.

The game uses two decks of cards, the Viking Deck and the Encounter Deck. The Viking Deck contains Ship, Crew, and Destination Cards. The Encounter Deck contains Sea, Defenders, and Treasure Cards.

The game ends when one player has successfully completed three raids or all other players have been sunk. The player with the most Gold wins.

38168.name: Victorian Villains
38168.description:
Heroes and villains of history and literature battle in this game of Victorian Era adventure.

Each player uses a separate deck, one for the heroes and one for the villains. Heroes portrayed in the game include Sherlock Holmes, Van Helsing, Tarzan, and Philieas Fog. Villains include Dr. Fu-Man-Chu, Jack the Ripper, and Thugee Assassins.

Masterminds attract Minions. Inventors and Scientists craft fantastic vehicles and weapons. Martian Tripods attempt world conquest. These events and more occur during the thirteen phases of each turn: New Day Phase, Genius Phase, Healing Phase, Minion Phase, Invention Phase, Recruit Phase, Plot Phase, Spy Phase, Assassin Phase, Plot Phase, Intercept Phase, Track Phase, and Attack Phase.

The goal is to eliminate all of your opponent's major characters. The first player to do so after the fifth turn wins the game.

38169.name: Wuxia
38169.description:
"Card Game for 2+ Players. Chinese Sword & Sorcery. Each Player is a Secret Society recruiting Sword fighters with Mystical Powers."

The game uses two card decks, the Recruit Deck and the Action Deck. The Recruit Deck has four card types: Fighters, Weapons, Events, and Enhancements. The Action Deck has six card types: Locales, Specials, Attack, Move, Defend, and Minions. Each player keeps a separate hand of cards for each deck.

The object of the game is to recruit fighters and defeat opposing fighters in duels. Each fighter has a Skill Rating. Fighters can have up to one Weapon Card and five Enhancement Cards attached. Most Fighters also have some sort of special ability.

To win, you must control at least four Fighters and kill all opposing fighters.

38170.name: The War in Heaven
38170.description:
"A long time ago, in a Universe far, far away, a race who had tyrannically ruled time and space in their Universe had to face the premature end of their Continuum. The end of the Universe was prompted by a powerful being known as Dionysus. Dionysus and some of his comrades escaped into the next Universe, which was an Antiverse to their original home. That Antiverse is our own present universe."

"The Virtuous Dionysus, his comrades from the previous Universe and righteous Empire at the end of time strive to protect our Universe from the invasion of the previous Time/ Space Continuum’s natives. Led by the mysterious Time’s Champion, the Exousia and Arche are struggling to establish a beachhead in our Universe (their Antiverse) from which they can write themselves into our Time Continuum’s history. Only Dionysus, the Empress, Archaggelos, Malak’s, and Clade, can prevent the self proclaimed Time’s Champion, the Imperiatrix, the Exousia, Arche and Shed from conquering our Time/ Space Continuum."

One player assumes the role of Dionysus, while the other plays Time’s Champion. Each player has a set of non-collectible cards to be played using the rules from the Magic: The Gathering.

38171.name: Tarot Wars
38171.description:
"CCG style rules for Tarot Decks. There are so many nice Tarot Decks it’s a shame not to game with them. Card game for 2+ players."

Each card in the Tarot deck is classified as a Character (with a designated Force value), Event, or Modifier Card. Character Cards stay in play until they are killed. Modifier Cards are attached to Characters. Event Cards are discarded as soon as they are played.

Each player starts with fifty Life Points. Each time a Character sustains damage, the amount is deducted from the controlling player's Life Points. The object of the game is to reduce your opponent to zero Life Points.

38172.name: The Great Traveling Circus Game
38172.description:
"Each player is the owner of a traveling circus."

A web published game for which you can make your own components, or you can use the board, pawns, money, houses, and hotels from a Monopoly set.

A custom deck of Act Cards will need to be created. Each card represents a carnival or circus act. There are four types of acts: acrobats, clowns, animals, and freaks. An Act Card is drawn any time a player lands on one of the spaces that requires any type of card to be drawn. The Monopoly cards are not used.

The game ends when the last card is drawn from the Act Deck. The player with the most money at the end of the game wins.

38173.name: Thieves Guild
38173.description:
"Players control rival Thieves Guilds in a Medieval Middle-Eastern city."

The game is played on an area map displaying the city. The city is divided into nine areas, some of which have special effects. The game uses a custom deck of ninety cards which provide for various events. Each turn a card is placed face down in each section of the map of the city. The players compete to win cards by placing thieves on them.

"Object: Have the most gold at the end of 10 turns. Each thief you control at the end of the game is worth 2 gold."

38174.name: Treasure Hunter
38174.description:
"Adventuring parties compete to claim the most treasure."

The game uses a custom deck containing over 140 cards. These include Hero Cards (used to build an adventuring party), Location Cards, Spell Cards, Magic Item Cards, Guardian Cards (foes and traps), Treasure Cards, and Event Cards.

"Object: After going through the deck once, the player with the most treasure points wins the game."

38175.name: Underdark Adventures
38175.description:
A boardgame set in the Dungeons & Dragons Underdark campaign setting. Each player starts with a party of six adventurers attempting to acquire and return with the Underdark Maps.

The game is played on a 40 space track. The first party to reach the end of the track obtains the Underdark Maps. That party must then return the Maps to the start space to win. However, if an opposing party is able to defeat the party carrying the Maps, then the victorious party obtains the Maps and may return them to the start space to win the game.

38176.name: Utopia
38176.description:
"Solo card, dice & record keeping game. Based on the old Intellivision Video Game. Build up your Island Paradise."

The only components required for play are the card deck, writing paper, a pencil and six-sided dice. The player starts with 100 Gold Bars and a population of 1000.

A turn consists of thirteen phases: Census Phase, Taxes Phase, Industry Phase, Housing Phase, Food Phase, Flip Phase, Fishing Phase, Farming Phase, Build Phase, Piracy Phase, Rebellion Phase, Hurricane Phase, and Score Phase.

The player keeps a running score based on the amount of gold earned each turn. The game ends after the deck has been gone through two times.

38177.name: Volley
38177.description:
“Two-player card game of Napoleonic Warfare."

Each player starts with 100 points of troops. The object of the game is to reduce the opponent's troop total to zero. Troop casualties are inflicted by playing melds during the Attack Phase.

The players share a common deck. The deck contains ten suits: Infantry Units, Infantry Weapons, Cavalry Units, Cavalry Weapons, Artillery Units, Artillery Weapons, Leaders, Strategy, Morale, and Defense.

A simplified version of Fusillade.

38178.name: War Wind
38178.description:
"Card game for 2-4 players. SF Theme. Based on the 1996 PC game."

The players play as one of four Clans: Tha’Roon, Obblinox, Eaggra, and Shama’Li.

Each player has a unique Settlement Card and Clan Deck. The players also share a common World Deck.

The object of the game is to eliminate opposing players by destroying their Settlements.

38179.name: Wizarding Duels
38179.description:
"Card game depicting a Wizard Duel in the Harry Potter Universe. Game for 2+ players. Each Player & Deck represents a single Character."

Wizard characters have twelve Stats: Alignment, House, Age, Race, Knowledge, Courage, Endurance, Speed, Aim, Experience, Intellect, and Power.

"Each player will have to make a deck for his Wizard (Character). A Wizard can be one from the stories or one you make up. The card list contains a list of every possible card. Choose cards appropriate to your Character (According to his Stats). A Deck should have a minimum of 40 cards. A Deck may contain no more than 1 copy of any single card."

The object of the game is to defeat the opposing Wizards. An wizard is defeated by being killed, immobilized, heavily wounded, knocked out, or by suffering memory loss.

38180.name: Wreckers
38180.description:
"Players are Maritime Salvage Companies searching the World’s waters for Treasure laden Shipwrecks. Card game for 2-4+ players."

The card deck contains seven types of cards: Search, Investor, Location, Controversy, Expenses, Wreck, and Delay. Discovery Tokens and Money Tokens are also required for play.

"At the end of 10 Rounds, the player with the most Money Wins. If tied in money, the player with the most Discovery Tokens wins."

38181.name: Super League
38181.description:
"Titanic Struggle between Rival Super Hero/Villain Teams."

The game uses two decks of cards - the Recruit Deck and the Action Deck. The Recruit Deck contains Heroes/Villains, Minions, Aids, Plots, and Upgrades Cards. The Action Deck contains Events and Battle Cards. Six-sided dice are also required for play.

"Victory: You win if all Heroes/Minions of the opposing Team are neutralized."

38182.name: Superman
38182.description:
“Card game for 2 or more players. Each player takes on the role of Superman on a similar but alternate parallel Earth. Players compete to see who captures the most powerful villains.”

The players attempt to play combinations of cards to capture Villains. A combination must include the Villain Card to be captured, together with up to two Weapon Cards and one Plot Card. These cards represent the total Villain Point Value. The player must then play a Superman card together with Power, Ally, and Equipment Cards having a higher total value than the Villain Point Value.

Opponents may then play Weapon and Plot Cards to aid the Villain. The player may then respond by playing additional Power, Ally, and Equipment Cards. If the total value of the Superman cards still exceeds the total Villain Point Value, the Villain is captured and placed in the players Prison Pile together with all Weapon and Plot Cards played to support the Villain.

The game ends after the last card is drawn from the deck. The winner is the player having a Prison Pile worth the most total points.

38183.name: Swords & Sorcery
38183.description:
A set of fantasy miniatures wargaming rules. One figure equals one man or creature. The game uses six-sided and twelve-sided dice.

The game contains unit costs and attributes for dozens of units. Classes of units include Dwarves, Elves, Goblins, Orcs, Medieval Men, Barbarians, Nomads, Undead, and Oriental units.

The rules cover distinctions between ranged, polearm, and hand-to-hand attacks. The rules also provide for flying units, morale and rally, spells, and special heroes.

38184.name: Trist
38184.description: "Trist is an abstract strategy game played on a grid of interlocking triangles. Players each get a supply of tokens of a unique color. Players take turns placing their tokens on the triangles. Only one token can be on a triangle. The winner is the first player to make a combination of six tokens.” Two optional rules are provided for play variation.

38185.name: Star Fiefs
38185.description:
“Card game version of N/A. Opposing Noble Houses vie for domination in this quadrant of space.”

Each player starts with one Homeworld Card, one Leader Card, four Power Tokens, and a hand of eight cards drawn from the deck. The game is played in the following phases: Intrigue, Event, Duel, Attack (Military or Political), Production, and Recruit. Leaders may be targeted for assassination or duels. Power Tokens are won from other players by making successful political attacks.

The object of the game is to become Governor of the Sector. You can do so by eliminating all of your opponents, or by being the first player to accumulate eight Power Tokens.

38186.name: Stargate Missions
38186.description:
"Dice & Card game for 2+ players. Based on the Stargate Universe." The game uses three card decks: Personnel, Missions, and Events.

The Personnel Deck is composed of the characters you control. There are two types of Personnel: Main Characters and Support Personnel. When teamed up, Support Personnel are always lost or killed before Main Characters. Personnel have stats in two characteristics, Brains and Combat, and possess one or more of the following skills: Science, Medical, Communication, and Lore.

The Game ends when there are no cards left to draw from the Mission Deck. The player with the highest Victory Score wins the game. The Victory Score is based on the total points of all Missions completed and the number of Personnel that were lost or killed.

38187.name: Phase 10 Twist
38187.description:
From the publisher:

Whether you are a longtime fan of Phase 10, or you're new to the game, take on the challenge of Phase 10 Twist! If you play your cards right, you can out-think your opponents and maximize your luck! Take risks and try to advance to the finish faster or play the safe and steady route... whichever way you want to play, you'll be challenged, excited, and even a little twisted.

From submitter:

This looks to add multiple draw piles, a board to progress upon and optional push your luck out of turn phase selections from a separate draw pile. It's still Phase 10, but it looks to have been brought some much needed gameplay additions.

38188.description:
Babel13, an expanded NY military base, has lost contact with its HQ. The lonely defenders must face an enemy they have never seen before: the forces of mutated nature, the Neojungle. The battle for survival begins.

Neuroshima Hex! Babel13 is the first Neuroshima Hex! expansion. In this box you'll find two new, unique armies (the heavily armored forces of New York and the Neojungle full of beasts). You'll also get terrain tiles that rebuild and modify the main board, allowing players to play different scenarios. The box also has a two-player campaign titled "Babel13" which allows players to play four closely connected scenarios which resolve in a deadly final game!
38188.name: Neuroshima Hex! Babel13

boardgamefamily.7757: From RPG books to board games

38189.description:
It’s the end of the year and with it comes the inevitable finals. You want to succeed. Did you study enough? Are you ready to do anything to do well? Really? Be careful though, the teacher is roaming the class and his pet are telling him everything that happens. Players are students secretly choosing an action, which will allow them to draw, exchange or play cards to score points. The riskier the action, the better the results but also the greater the consequences for failing or getting caught.

This print and play game was initially developed as Exam 101 (above). However it is also available in 2 other skins: "Shiver me Timbers!" (Pirate theme) and "The lair of Dr. Uptonogood" (Spy theme).

Rules and Print and play files coming soon.
38189.name: Exam 101

boardgamefamily.4705: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

38190.name: Rekenen met Dora
38190.description:
Child's game about learning how to count. The correct puzzle pieces must be put together with the correct number of symbols on the tiles.

"Counting with Dora the Explorer"

38191.description:
Pantery w akcji (Kaniów 1943) (Panthers in action - Kanev 1943) presents the situation in late 1943.

After the fall at Kursk, the German army was withdrawing to the West. The major obstacle for the Red Army was the Dniepr river, especially since south of Kiev only one bridge was left - the railway one near Kanev.
Expecting an attack of Kiev, the German forces were unprepared for a Soviet attack aimed at siezing the bridge. Combined Armoured Corps and airborne units soon threatened to have the German forces cut off from the Western bank of the river. The situation was to be rescued by reinforcements of 19th and 7th Panzer Divisions but they come to late - the Dniepr was taken by Red Army.

The game uses rules of the B35 (Battles of World War II 1943-1945) system designed for dealing with medium battles of World War II. Counters represent battalions (Germans) or regiments (Russians), one hex represents 1500m, one turn represents 12 hours.
38191.name: Pantery w akcji (Kaniów 1943)

38192.description:
Czerwony Huragan (Red Thunderstorm) presents the last months of the Third Reich. The Southern Group of Soviet forces starts the final strike into the heart of Germany - Berlin. Field Marschal Koniev is competing with Zukhow to be the first to reach Berlin.
The first strike of Soviet forces is overwhelming - they break through German lines and move forward, but the Germans do not give up. They pull up their last remaining reinforcements and counter at the stretched south flank of the Red Army, which happens to be the Polish II Army. The fierce and bloody battle begins where prisoners are not taken.

The game uses rules of the "WB95" (Great Battles 1939-1945) system designed for dealing with large battles of World War II. Counters represent regiments (Germans) or divisions (Russians), one hex represents about 2500m, one turn represents one day.
38192.name: Czerwony Huragan (Budziszyn 1945)

boardgamehonor.41172: 2014 UK Games Expo Best General Card Game  Winner

38194.description: The card game Cheaty Mages puts you in the role of a wizard who has come to watch and bet on monsters fighting in an arena. Of course, you have all of your spells to help the monsters you've bet on win (or harm the monsters fighting against yours) – but then again, so do all of the other players, too! What's more, judges line the arena during combat and if players push things too far with their cheating spells, a judge might intervene and dispel – or even eject – the fighter! Who will walk away with the largest pile of gold?
38194.name: Cheaty Mages!

38195.description:
Players move around a 7x7 grid of many sets of goat cards, milk can cards, and herding dog cards, picking up one card each turn from the row their goat token lands next to.

Cards are spent from a hand of two cards, first as movement points to keep moving around the grid on a subsequent turn, and second as melds to try to collect 8 points from a set of five goat cards numbered 1-5.

Once 8 points is achieved, the remaining cards in that set of five cards are marked on the grid as belonging to that player, and those are the main victory points in the game. (There is a secondary way to score by collecting milk cans.) Players try to get the 8 points in several different sets as the game progresses.

Once a player has some goats on the grid, the herding dog cards become useful. They are played to move his cards on the grid into a player's home scoring area -- the original "pen of goats" square he starts the game with, or any square contiguous to this gradually expanding area -- where the points are doubled.
38195.name: Herr der Ziegen

38196.name: Relic Raiders: Treasure of the Lost Pyramid
38196.description: An innovative 3-D pop-up game (no assembly required), in which each player has to discover what the treasure at the top of the pyramid is. Players can actually physically move the pathways on the 3-D game board to either improve their own route or hinder their opponents' route.

38197.name: Relic Raiders: Haunted Ruins
38197.description: An innovative 3-D pop-up game (no assembly required), in which each player has to find a way out of the haunted ruins, and avoid the zombie. Players can actually physically move the pathways on the 3-D game board to either improve their own route or hinder their opponents' route.

38200.description: Uncommon Valor is the first in a three-module series depicting the Battle of Iwo Jima. The game re-creates the confrontation at Motoyama Airfield #2, a war waged with the most vicious weapons available to the combatants, including flame-throwing ‘Zippo’ Shermans and Japanese heavy artillery. Eight scenarios and a campaign game are included, along with special rules to take the gamer back in time to the contested...and critical, airfield on the hellish island of Iwo Jima.
38200.name: Uncommon Valor

38201.name: Trans-Kombi
38201.description:
Trans-Kombi is the abbreviation of Transportkombination, or combination of transports. Players play in two teams, with each team playing of their own identical board that shows the major town and transport connections of the former German Democratic Republic. A game master is recommended.
The game is played in 3 rounds. Each round 6 town cards are drawn. The first card of the first round is the common start point, the other 5 are the stations each teams must connect in the order of their choice. Each team's last station is its next starting point, and the original start is the common end point of the last round.
Each team starts with a credit which is needed to buy the transport- black for rails, red for streets, blue for waterways and green for air transport. Prices are rolled for before each round. Also, each round has an accident field that is secretly determined beforehand and often requires re-building a section of the route. Rails, roads and waterways must follow the lines printed on the board, while air transport always takes the shortest possible route.
Teams compete to complete the route first (to get a bonus) and as effectively (=cheaply) as possible. The team with most cash at the end of round 3 wins.

38202.description:
You are starving. You are in the middle of Chinatown and only one restaurant is open. Oh no! The menu is written only in Chinese. You only know 5 Chinese characters, one for each meal type (beef, chicken, lamb, fish and vegetables). For each meal type, you are hesitating between two Chinese characters. You will have to try to order using your very limited knowledge of the language. The waiter, slightly confused, will bring you what he thinks the majority wants. The player who successfully orders the most meals will score the most points and win.
The players will do this by predicting which meal type is the most abundant in a common pile of Meal cards. To help them, they will be able to add Meal cards to the pile. However, the more cards they add to the pile, the less prediction they will be allowed to make. To win, a player will have to balance memory, risk-taking and bluffing.

The game is made of 110 cards.
38202.name: It's All Chinese to Me!

38203.name: Noah's Ark Animal Match
38203.description:
Noah's Ark Animal Match Game

(c)1990 Jewish Educational Toys

"Help Noah gather all the animals into the Ark!"

Players match picture cards to the animals shown on the Ark gameboard. Includes a colorful board, 4 plastic tokens, 25 animal cards, and rules.

Designed for Ages 4 - 10 with no reading required.

38204.name: How to Host a Dungeon
38204.description:
How to Host a Dungeon is a solo fantasy pen-and-paper dungeon-building game. The game follows the progress of an imaginary dungeon from the dawn of time through to an arch villain attempting to conquer the world.

The creation of the dungeon is driven by random tables and procedures as monsters, adventurers, civilizations, and arch villains interact in an underground environment. The player records these interactions, maintains the dungeon map, and makes some choices in how they play out.

The end product of the game is a complete unique dungeon map and history which stands as an interesting artifact on its own or can be used as the basis of a dungeon crawl role-playing game campaign.

Download the free version or order the game here: How to Host a Dungeon.

boardgamehonor.21286: 2008 Charles S. Roberts Best Desktop Published (DTP) Game Nominee

38205.description:
This is a DTP game, with a sticky back counter sheet to mount. It is a two-player game set in 1983, with one person playing the U.S., and the other person playing the Soviet Union. The game comes with two programmed scenarios, Bolt from the Blue (a one turn scenario) and First Strike (standard ten turn scenario) and instructions for varying the First Strike scenario if desired.

As would be expected in a game featuring nuclear war, it is quite possible for both players to lose utterly. Also, one side can lose utterly, while the other side may not achieve "victory conditions" in game terms. All involved in the design and production of this game make it clear that if this hypothetical situation had played out, incredible horrors would have been unleashed upon the world and there would not have been any winners in any real sense.

From the designer:
"First Strike is a game about thermonuclear war between the superpowers during the Cold War, in November 1983. This is based on actual historic incidents and persons wishing to become acquainted with them can read 'Comrade Kryuchov's Instructions', about Operation Ryan, or 'War Scare: Russia and America on the Nuclear Brink'"
38205.name: First Strike

38206.description:
This is a DTP game, with a sticky back sheet of counters that must be mounted.

It is a two player game that covers the Japanese invasion of Singapore in early 1942, one of the most embarrassing defeats of the British Empire. One person plays the British/Australian forces attempting to defend Singapore. The other person plays the invading Japanese.
The British player is basically fighting a delaying action, with the goal of preventing the Japanese from achieving their goals prior to the end of the game.
38206.name: Illusionary Fortress

38207.description:
Wildfire Overkill, the first expansion to the Wildfire science fiction miniatures skirmish game! At 50 pages and available in book and pdf form, Overkill includes a small number of rules clarifications from the main rulebook based on player feedback, followed by a whole host of optional rules to enrich your games including: playing in 25mm, new weapon types, stealth and camouflage, tracking devices, troop dispositions and leaders, targeting priorities and more! Finally, six army lists are provided detailing example troops, vehicles and weapons from your favorite science fiction fims and books for easy 'pick up and play' gaming. Wildfire Overkill takes science fiction skirmish gaming to the next level - why not come along for the ride?

Expands:

Wildfire
38207.name: Wildfire Overkill

38208.description:
Air Umbrella Over Dunkirk is an extension module to the "Down In Flames"-Series - Volume 1: The Rise of the Luftwaffe game by GMT.

The British Expeditionary Force was facing total annihilation after the lightning campaign waged by the Germans in France and the Low Countries. Deciding to rest the Panzer divisions, Hitler entrusted Goering's Luftwaffe with the mission of smashing the British evacuation at Dunkirk. The already thinly stretched RAF had to provide an air umbrella to protect the stream of ships plying the English Channel. Although the British lost the equivalent of six squadrons of fighter aircraft plus a large number of ships sunk or damaged they managed to evacuate over 300,000 Allied soldiers, including the bulk of the BEF.
38208.name: Down in Flames: Air Umbrella Over Dunkirk

38209.description:
A Rise of the Luftwaffe campaign module from RBM/GMT's C3i Magazine Nr5, Winter War 1939-40 is an extension part/ module to the "Down In Flames"-Series - Volume 1: Rise of the Luftwaffe game by GMT.

In late 1939 the Soviet Union began preparing for a possible war with Germany, despite having signed a non-aggression pact with Hitler in August. To strengthen its western defences, the USSR absorbed the Baltic states and made exorbitant demands for territorial concessions from Finland.

"Down in Flames" series is a card-driven game that simulate WW2 air combat.
38209.name: Down In Flames: Winter War 1939-40

38210.description:
The Netherlands East Indies is an extension part/ module to the "Down In Flames"-Series - Volume 2: Zero! game by GMT Games. This DiF Module was published in RBM's C3i Magazine Nr14.

The invasion of the Netherlands East Indies began on 11 January 1942 when Japanese troops based in the Philippines landed on Borneo and the Celebes. Two weeks later, other Japanese troops, using Malaya as a staging area, invaded Sumatra.

"Down in Flames" series is a card-driven game that simulate WW2 air combat.
38210.name: Down in Flames: The Netherlands East Indies

38211.description:
Java is an extension part/ module to the Down In Flames Series - Volume 2: Zero! game by GMT Games. This DiF Module was published in RBM's C3i Magazine Nr14.

The conquest of Borneo, the Celebes, Amboin, Timor, Lombok and Bali in February 1942 left the Japanese in complete control of eastern part of the Netherlands East Indies, while the conquest of Sumatra late that month gave them possesssion of the west end of the archipelago. All that remaines was Java.
On 1 March 1942 the Japanese landed troops on both the east and west ends of the island. The defenders fought back valiantly but had to capitulate nine days later.

Down in Flames series is a card-driven game that simulate WW2 air combat.
38211.name: Zero!: Java – Module

38212.name: The Angry Monster Machine
38212.description: This game is designed to help children find constructive ways to express anger. At the start of the game, each player creatures four monsters from Play-Doh modeling compound using the provided mold and places them at different locations: School, Community, Playground and Home. The players then roll dice and move plastic trucks around the board in an effort to capture the monsters and return them to the monster machine at the center of the board. When a player returns a monster to the machine, he or she talks about something from the monster's source that causes anger, then chooses a "Transformer Card" featuring an appropriate resolution to the anger. The card directs the player to reform the monster into another shape. The first player to transform all four of his or her monsters wins the game.

38214.name: Acronymity: Trivia Edition
38214.description: This follow-up to Acronymity takes things a step further -- while the original game was about defining acronyms, this game features trivia questions whose answers are acronyms. Players get to move forward 1-3 spaces for answering the correct acronym, 4-6 spaces for answering AND defining the acronym. Special spaces on the game board add further variation to play through challenges, all-play events, and changes to the meanings of dice rolls. Team play is encouraged.

38215.name: Subbuteo Penalty Shootout
38215.description:
Subbuteo Penalty Shootout is a football (soccer game). It focuses on penalty taking. The attacking player flicks his Player to shoot the ball into the goal. The defending player operates the goalkeeper on a stick to defend the penalty kick. After taking 5 penalties each, the player with the most goals is the winner.

A self contained game, it is designed to encourage younger players to build their skills ready for the full Subbuteo game. Promotional version available in conjunction with Nestle Yorkie.

38216.description: A single-sided Conflict of Heroes battlefield board for featuring a swamp. The board was initially released at Origins 2008.
38216.name: Conflict of Heroes Expansion Pack: Map Board #6 – The Marsh

132028.name: Conflict of Heroes: Awakening the Bear! (second edition)

38217.description:
The Overrunning of the West was the second installment of The History of the Second World War series. Part 2 covers the battles for Western Europe through 1941. Scenarios include: The Overrunning of Poland, The Overrunning of Norway, The Overrunning of the West, The Battle of Britain, The Overrunning of the Balkans and Crete, and a campaign game.

Part 2: The Overrunning of the West was a complete game in itself. It had all the rules and components necessary to play any of the scenarios of Part 2 (except dice), but was designed to be played with The History of the Second World War - Part 1: Hitler Turns Against Russia. Units are Fleets and Armies. Game scale is approximately 175 miles(280 kilometers) per hex.
38217.name: The Overrunning of the West

3645.name: History of the Second World War

38218.name: Jumping DJ
38218.description:
This is themed after Dishonest John and the characters from the Beany & Cecil cartoon.

This is a surprise action game for 2 to 6 players. Dishonest John is a spring loaded timer that is pressed down after all the 44 cards with the extra Dishonest john card is dealt out to all the players. Players then take turns passing one card to the opponent on their left until Dishonest John springs up which ends the round. You then score your hand based on how many cards you have of the different suits (pairs, three of a kind, four of a kind, and etc.). The person stuck holding the Dishonest John card gets minus 30 points for it. You keep playing another round until someone scores 250 points and is declared the winner.

38219.name: ling-whist
38219.description:
"The learn a language game.
Card game excitement while learning to speak Spanish/French."

Contents:
Phrase Book, Rules
120 Ling-Whist playing cards with letters and pronunciations.

Seven cards are dealt to each player, and a phrase is selected from the phrase book. During a turn a player draws a card and either discards a card or plays one to his current word. The word must be from the phrase chosen; it must be spelled in correct order, but the words themselves can be done in any order. The game ends when someone completes the sentence or the deck runs out, and players score:

for each player, 5 points for each completed word
for the player with the fewest points in hand, the difference between the opponent's hand and theirs
for winning, 25 points
plus the points on all the cards in the sentence
plus the points on incomplete words by the others
all doubled if the opponents did not complete a word, tripled if they didn't get a letter down





300 points wins the game.

Language practice comes in by reciting the chosen phrase, saying the letter's name when playing its card (e.g. 'HO-tah', not 'jay'), and reciting the phrase again when you repeat it.

38220.description:
The 18xx MSK-3 extension kit updated the rulebook and added 4 pound notes to the game.
Expands:
* 1829
* 1829 Northern Board
38220.name: MSK 3 Extension Kit for 1829 (Northern & Southern Boards)

38221.description:
The 18xx MSK 5 extension kit adds 8 tiles: 2 of #55 (yellow), 2 of #56(yellow), 2 of #69 (1853-style, not 1830 style -yellow), and 2 of #11 (green), with a half-page of rules for their use.

Expands:

* 1829
* 1829 Northern Board
38221.name: MSK 5 Extension Kit for 1829 (Northern & Southern Boards)

38222.description:
The 18xx MSK-6 extension kit adds 8 tiles (3 of #52, 1 of #64, 1 of #65, 1 of #66, 1 of #67, and 1 of #68.) with a half-page of rules for their use.

Expands:

* 1829
* 1829 Northern Board
38222.name: MSK 6 Extension Kit for 1829 (Northern & Southern Boards)

38223.name: Mjollnir
38223.description:
The game of Mjollnir is named after the Norse God Thor's
mighty hammer which he could throw at an enemy and it
would always return to his hand after smashing his opponent.
Variations of these bluffing dice games were played all over
Scandinavia and were a fun way to pass the time around the
fire pit of a Viking long house during the long winter nights.

Mjollnir is a pretty easy game to learn and comes with
a game rules parchment. Besides playing Mjollnir, you can
use the dice and "shaker" box to play many other popular
dice games because each die is marked from 1 to 6 but with
our unique symbols such as Odin One-Eye or Freya's Tears

Each Mjollnir Game comes with a pair of Custom Dice
a dozen glass "gems" which are enough to start off four players
a complete "Rules" parchment and an attractively decorated
"Shaker" box that doubles as a storage container for your
dice and gems. The box is decorated using Pyrography or
wood burning which was a common technique in the
age of the Vikings.

38224.description:
Sixth entry in the English Civil War series, features three different battles, Lansdown, Roundway Down and Cheriton, each with a separate map (in a A4 sheet) and a total of around 150 counters.
These are fast and furious battles, with very few counters and a mechanic (chit drawing for the activation of leaders) that is very good both for solitaire than competitive play.

Available as direct download (then print & play) through Wargamedownloads.com

The English Civil War battle of Lansdowne (or Lansdown) was fought on July 5, 1643, near Bath. Although the Royalists under Lord Hopton forced the Parliamentarians under Sir William Waller to retreat from their hilltop position, they suffered so many casualties themselves and were left so disordered and short of ammunition that an injured Hopton was forced to retire.

The Battle of Roundway Down was fought on July 13, 1643, during the English Civil War. A Royalist cavalry force under Lord Wilmot won a crushing victory over the Parliamentarians under Sir William Waller who were besieging Devizes in central Wiltshire, which was defended by Lord Hopton.

The Battle of Cheriton was an important Parliamentarian victory in the English Civil War. It took place on March 29, 1644 and resulted in the defeat of a Royalist army, which threw King Charles I onto the defensive for the remainder of the year.

Contains:
6 Page Rules
3 8.5x11" Maps
1 Player Aid
159 Counters
38224.name: Hopton vs. Waller

38226.name: Flibbix
38226.description:
Flibbix is a "make-your-own" board game, the first game by Merillian Games. The board consists of a series of magnetic tiles which can be flipped for different effects. A game begins by laying out the tiles (Merillian provides some sample layouts, but you can create your own order) and selecting various rules from a checklist (who goes first, what happens if you land on another player, etc.).

Once everything is set up, it's a roll-and-move board game with the addition of cards that allow you to move extra spaces, swap places with other players, swap tiles on the board, or flip tiles over.

Flibbix is a combination of Flip, Blend, and Mix, describing the way that the game is played.

38227.description:
Wolsung: The Boardgame is a large family game for 2 to 4 players. They act as inventors and industrialists living in a fictional steampunk world, largely similar to the Victorian times. The inventors develop extraordinary constructions – steam cars, golems and zeppelins – in the race for the title of the best designer at the World’s Fair.

The objective of the game is to build the best and the most unique machines – players compete against each other for plans of the devices as well as for the resources necessary to build them.

The game contains multiple elements: the board, auxiliary boards (players’ workshops), a 55-card deck, numerous tokens and wooden markers and a surprise gadget being the key element of the game mechanics.
The board game constitutes the first product of the Wolsung Project, which includes publishing a modern role-playing game "Wolsung: Magic of the Steampunk Age" (in Polish) as well as other games and expansion packs to them and gadgets such as playing card decks and special dice.

The game contains the following components:

- the board
- 3 combines
- the deck of 55 cards
- 4 workshops
- 84 wooden worker tokens
- 76 wooden resource tokens
