- 12 wooden upgrade tokens
- 1 round marker
- 1 first engineer marker
- the rulebook
38227.name: Wolsung: The Boardgame

38228.description:
A game from "Dragon Hobby" magazine (10) 2/2000 about the Austro-Hungarian and Russian fight near Krasnik and Zamosc in August 1914.

The game's rules are based on Tannenberg 1914 rules.
38228.name: Galicja 1914

38229.name: GiocaGoal
38229.description:
Giocagoal was a game manufactured by Atlantic, a firm very well known in Italy during the first half of the 70's for their wide range of 1:72 and 1:32 scale soldiers, tanks, dioramas.

Occasionally they did something out of the military range.

GiocaGoal was a simple simulation of a football game, much smaller and cheaper than Subbuteo. It was sold in boxes that contained just half of the pitch, balls, a complete team, coach, bench, referee and a goal.

The plastic figures were made by a round and hollow flat base into which the actual figure (different poses according to their role) had to be pressed in. Colours represented teams of the Italian Serie A of the time, so you could buy your favourite team. To play you needed at least two boxes in order to form the complete playing area. The figures were flicked more or less as in Subbuteo. The most used ball was a semi-spheric one, because the round one was too difficult to control properly.

Don't remember if there was a set of rules in the box or if we just made our own

A few months later, at the end of 1973, Atlantic published the Super GiocaGoal. Same players, but a larger pitch.

38230.name: Pagamás!
38230.description:
Pagamás! is a fun mischievous little card game where each player controls a crew member of a pirate ship (Captain, Second, Bosco, Vigie, Chaplain or Cambuse), driven by one thing: greed.

Every evening at the port (each round), the Captain distributes the booty trying to satisfy his crew members as much as possible but also trying to get most of it for himself. But he can not satisfy everyone. For the crew members the only way to get a fair share is either by boot licking the Captain or by trying to take his place. To achieve ones goals everything is allowed: conspiracies, betrayals, decoys and mutiny.

Currently Pagamás! is available in French only.

Home Page: http://www.pagamas.fr/

38231.name: Turn Over
38231.description: Turn-Over is a game where you place one of the "Turn-Overs" which is an aluminum capsules with metal ball bearings on the board and you shift the board around and try to score points by having them fall into a holes that are worth different amounts of points.

38232.name: Math War
38232.description:
Players take turns laying down cards and giving the answer to the problem on their card. The highest correct answer always takes the trick. Play continues until one player has won all the cards.

Contains 54 playing cards plus a Parent card (the rules) and an Equation card (an answer list)

38233.name: Takeover
38233.description:
"Card game for 2+ players. Each player represents a group of investors trying to buy a target Company. Of course they are competing with rival groups."

The game uses a custom deck of cards. There are two types of cards in the deck: Investor Cards and Tactics Cards. The object of the game is to hold the most shares at the end of the game, thereby winning control of the company.

38234.name: Color Gin
38234.description:
Color Gin was published in A Gamut of Games. It is a game derived from Gin Rummy, but you must score points separately for all four suits. So effectively you are playing four games at the same time.

You score points in the same way as Gin Rummy, but the following condition prevents you from scoring in a suit:
An unmatched card
A sequence stop
Missing suit in a three of a kind.

You can only go if you can score in at least one game, and as any player scores 100 points total in a suit, that suit stops counting points, so you must pay attention have points only in suits that are now worthless.

38235.name: Alaska Adventure
38235.description: According to the box, a fun game that tours "The Land of the Midnight Sun." The object is to be the first player to reach Polar Bear Field. The components are a board, a die, and five translucent plastic tokens.

38237.name: Ökoly
38237.description:
"Buy a flock of sheep - Construct a flour mill - Convert a hog feeding facility into an organic farm - or even Tear down a nuclear power plant - this all is possible in Ökoly: The only way of winning is by acting ecologically"

This introduction to Ökoly as printed on its box already provides a first flavour of this game. Similar to monopoly, the players move around a quadrangle and buy property within a city and collect revenue from the others. However, money is just a means to the end to act ecologically, i.e. collecting more Eco-Points (EP) than the other players.

These EPs can be collected in different ways:
- conversion of an "ecologically unfriendly" business (e.g. automotive, hog feeding or warfare) to an ecological friendly one (solar, bio-gas, wind energy)
- extending a business ecologically
- helping other players out of insolvency
- passing a turn by working at the welfare centre or an other player's business
- tearing down the nuclear power station collectively with other players

The ecological theme, beautifully carved wooden meeples, hand designed playing cards and money (all printed on recycled paper), health-food shops as a distribution channel and a DM3,- contribution to Greenpeace (deducted from the purchase price) made Ökoly a real innovator at the beginning of the 1980's in Germany.

38238.name: Hopshot
38238.description:
Hopshot -- the Hip-Hoppin', Kangaroo-Jumpin', Basketball Game.

In this game players each take a Kangaroo of a certain color and attempt to flick small plastic balls into it's pouch. The lever for each kangaroo controls a baby kangaroo from which the balls are thrown into the pouch. Recommended for Ages 4 and up.

38239.name: Juicy Words
38239.description: Juicy Words, called "The Game of Oral Delights," is the sequel to the game Dirty Words. Whereas in Dirty Words, the verbs were sexually suggestive and the nouns were mostly body parts, in Juicy Words most of the verbs connote eating, and most of the nouns are fruits and vegetables

38240.description:
"Two player abstract strategy board game. Variant of Backgammon."

The game is played on a standard checkers board and requires sixteen red checkers, sixteen black checkers, and two six-sided dice.

"Each player gets one set of 16 checkers. Each player has his own 'side of the board.' On the back row of a players side, the player places a stack of 8 checkers in each of the two corner spaces. Red moves first."

"Checkers may be moved forward, to the left sideways, and to the right sideways. Checkers may not be moved diagonally or backwards."

The first player to move all of the player's checkers off the board from the opponent's back row wins the game.
38240.name: Wargammon

38241.name: WH40K Squads
38241.description:
A two-player squad level card game based on the Games Workshop Warhammer 40,000 universe.

Each player uses a separate deck, depending on the force the player is leading. There are decks for the Space Marine Squads, Ork Squadz, Eldar Squads, Chaos Space Marine Squads, and Tyranid Brood. The cards represent Units, Attachments (weapons), and Events. The Units are primarily squad sized.

The players deploy Units, which may be accompanied by Attachments, and all units in play can attack an opposing unit once per turn. All combat is considered simultaneous, so every unit has a chance to attack, even on a turn in which it is destroyed.

The object of the game is to eliminate all of your opponent’s cards.

38242.name: WH40KARDS
38242.description:
"Two player Card Game based on the Games Workshop Epic Warhammer 40,000 Universe."

Each player uses a separate deck, depending on the army the player is leading. There are decks for the Ork, Imperial, Eldar, Squat, and Chaos forces. Each unit is rated for movement, hits, close combat, attack, range, and type. The units are divided into three different types: Infantry, Vehicle, and Titan.

The players deploy up to three units at a time, positioned at left, right, and center. An additional unit is deployed by one of the players to reflect a flanking maneuver. Units then exchange attacks which are resolved by die roll.

“Victory: The first player to have 30 hits worth of his own units destroyed breaks and leaves the field. Or 40 if you have a Command unit deployed. 50 if you have a Leader unit deployed. If a player loses 3 turns in a row (has all his units in 3 turns destroyed) he breaks and routs.”

38243.name: Wizards School
38243.description:
"Players are young apprentices at their first semester of Wizards school."

"There are 6 fields of study that adepts accumulate lesson points in: Divination, Conjuration, Alchemy, Transformation, Invocation, and Extra Curricular Activities."

"The semester lasts 17 weeks. The game ends at the end of turn 17."

"The player who, at the end of the game, has accumulated the most lesson points in the most Fields of Study is the winner. If there is a tie, then the tied player with the most lesson points wins."

38244.name: Wizardly
38244.description:
"Each player controls a Covenant of Wizards. Players try to build up the prestige of their Covenant by Accumulating Victory Points."

The game is played using a custom deck of cards. There are seven types of cards in the deck: Wizards, Spells, Followers, Quests, Events, Items, and Duel.

The players earn Victory Points for controlling Wizards and Resources. Victory Points are also awarded for completing Quests. The first player to reach 25 Victory Points wins the game.

38245.name: Wizards Game
38245.description:
"Card game between rival Wizards."

Each player randomly selects a wizard character to play. Each wizard has a unique special ability. The card deck contains magical ingredients, spells, abilities, knowledge, and magical items that the wizards may possess or create.

The players keep track of three types of points during the game. Lore Points, gained through research, are used for Bidding to acquire cards. Heka Points are used to play Spell Cards. Fate Points are used to determine the winner at the end of the game. Having certain cards in play will generate Fate and Heka Points each turn.

"The first player to accumulate 25+ Fate points is the winner."

38246.name: Word Poker
38246.description:
A word game played using cards. The deck contains forty-seven cards, three of which are Wild Cards. The remainder of the cards have a letter of the alphabet marked on them.

The game is played in a seven card draw fashion. The players attempt to form words with the seven cards in their hand. Proper names are not allowed.

The value of the possible hands are ranked as follows, from lowest to highest: three letter word, two three letter words, four letter word, four letter word with three letter word, followed by five, six, and seven letter words. Each hand is also ranked with a point value.

38248.name: Warborn
38248.description:
A card game of fantasy combat for two or more players. The game uses a deck with eight types of cards: Heroes, Weapons, Armor, Mounts, Armies, Actions, Traits, and Spells.

Each round, the players draw hands of twelve cards. The players simultaneously play a meld of one hero and one other card from the other seven types.

The players then take turns activating cards in their meld. Depending on the type of card activated, this may allow players to add to their melds, to draw new cards from the deck, or to cause an opponent's card to be discarded. A player may also choose to pass rather than activating a card. If all of the players consecutively pass, the round ends and the winner of the round is determined based on the total force value of each player's meld.

The winner is the first player to win five rounds.

The designer notes: "I was working on a Heroscape mod and this is where I wound up."

38249.name: Sword & Shield
38249.description:
A rulebook for fantasy combat at various scales using miniature figures.

"Sword and Shield is for individual combat in the world of Acquitaine, and deals with realistic combat (jousts, tourneys, trial by combat and actual melee combat) as well as some of the fantastic denizens of Acquitaine."

"Concept based upon the novel, Shadowstalker, and stories of Eril Shadowstalker and Windsinger."

The rules cover individual combat, mass combat, jousting, sieges and siege equipment.

38250.name: La Legion Etrangere
38250.description:
A set of miniatures rules for gaming battles involving the French Foreign Legion, 1850-1930.

"This is a set of miniatures and role-playing rules, and as such has two separate combat systems. Although these systems are separate in the functions they fulfill, they are integrated in the sense that it allows an individual to take part in a larger action."

One of the combat systems governs "large scale battles", which use four figures to a stand for legionnaires and five to six figures to a stand for "native and rabble" units. The large scale battle system includes rules for ranged fire, melee fire, machine guns, and artillery.

The game includes two hex maps. One shows the layout of an Algerian village and the other is a map of a Foreign Legion fort.

38251.name: University
38251.description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Each player represents a University."

The players play as one of two types of universities: "A Public University gets to draw 1 extra card on its first turn. A Private University may put 1 specialty card into play during the game."

The card deck includes five types of cards: School, Facility, Title, Specialty, and Event Cards. Event Cards have various effects. All of the other cards are used to describe characteristics of the player's university.

School Cards come in six suits: Associates Degree, Bachelors Degree, Masters Degree, Doctorate Degree, Research Institution, and World Class Institution. Each suit is worth a different amount of Curriculum Points. Facility, Title, and Specialty cards also add to the player's Curriculum Points total.

"The Player with the most Curriculum points at the end of the game wins."

38252.name: War Jhong
38252.description:
A card game with an ancient Chinese warfare theme.

The deck has three suits: Infantry, Archers, and Cavalry. Each contains twenty seven cards numbered from one to nine (three cards with each number). There are also two Honor Suits which are not numbered, Junks and Forts, and two Special Suits, Generals and Tactics. General Cards may be discarded for victory points and Tactics cards are wild cards.

"Be the first player to accumulate 100 Victory Points. Points are scored for each hand when a player goes out. A player goes out by making 4 sets of 3 cards each. Only the player that went out scores points."

38253.name: United States
38253.description:
"Educational Geography card game. Subject: The United States of America." For two or more players, with variant scoring rules for solo play.

The game uses a deck of fifty cards, each of which names one of the the U.S. states. The players are seeking to play melds of three or more cards consisting of states which are all adjacent to each other or which form a chain of adjacent states.

The winner is the player who has played the most state cards. Variant rules are provided for easier games and other educational exercises suitable for use with the cards.

38254.name: Turtle Run
38254.description:
"Board & Dice game for 2 players. Each player controls a nest of newly hatched baby sea turtles trying to make their way across the beach to the sea."

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. One edge of the board represents the ocean shore. The row on the opposite end of the board is the Nest Row, where the players' nests are located. Each player starts with six baby sea turtle tokens in the player's nest. There are three predator tokens - the crab, gull, and raccoon.

"The player who gets the most of his turtles off the map & into the Sea wins."

38255.name: Titan Attack
38255.description:
"Two player Card Game based on the Games Workshop Epic Warhammer 40,000 Universe."

Each player uses a separate deck, depending on the army the player is leading. There are decks for the Ork Gargant, Imperial Titan, Eldar Titan, and Chaos Titan forces. Each deck contains fifty-five cards.

The players attempt to make three card melds consisting of a Titan Card, Weapon Card, and Range Card.

The object of the game is to get the other player to run out of cards.

38256.name: Time to Tell
38256.description:
"Educational Party game for 2-8+ players. Players must answer trivia type questions involving Historical dates."

The game involves arranging cards listing historical events into chronological order. The number of cards that must be arranged, from two to five, is randomly determined. If the player is able to arrange the cards in correct order, he receives a chip for each card.

The first player to accumulate twenty-five chips is the winner.

38257.name: Tic-Tac-Tics
38257.description:
"Abstract Game for 2 Players. Tac-tac-toe variant with a regular deck of cards and played on 3 Boards."

"Each board is a 3 x 3 grid. Each space (square) on each board is numbered. The Spaces on a board are numbered 1 through 9. Each player gets 1 Home Board. The third board which is placed between the players is called the Mid Board."

Card play allows you to transfer one of your pieces to another board or to switch your piece's position for that of another.

"To achieve victory, you must get two simultaneous three-in-a- rows (TIARS). TIARS cannot be on your Home Board. You could have both TIARS on your opponents board or the Mid board, or 1 TIAR each on the Mid board and your opponent’s board. If both TIARS are on the same board, they may share a space."

38258.name: The Diet Game
38258.description:
"Gamers are trying to lose weight prior to their 15 year high school reunion. Card game for 2+ players."

There are seven types of cards in the game: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner, Snack, Cheat, Exercise, and Negate. With the exception of the Negate Cards, all of the cards are marked with an amount of weight gain or loss. Play weight loss cards on yourself and weight gain cards on your opponents.

"Winning: Be the First player to lose 10 pounds. (i.e. score of –10)"

38259.description:
MIK2 Extension Kit for 1853 (Shares and Commodities)

Contents:
* Two Director's certificates for the Bengal Assam Railway, 140 Pounds Each
* Four Director's certificates for the Bombay, Baroda & Central India Railway, 168 Pounds Each
* Two Director's certificates for the Bengal Nagpur Railway, 176 Pounds Each
* Four Director's certificates for the Great Indian Peninsula Railway, 192 Pounds Each
* Four Director's certificates for the Madras & Southern Mahratta Railway, 160 Pounds Each
* Four commodity cards (Coal, Cotton, Rice, Tea)
* One Disturbances card
* Six place cards (1 to 6)
* One rules sheet

Comments:
When using this kit, control of a company now rests with whoever holds the majority of Director's certificates. Commodity cards permit ordinary track to be changed into stations and thus represent the revenue that can be earned by goods traffic. The Disturbances card closes a chosen city for one round.

The rules sheet contains alternative rules for 1853, which include the use of the place cards in this kit to determine the seating order.

Expands:

1853
38259.name: MIK 2 Extension Kit for 1853

38260.description:
MIK1 Extension Kit for 1853

Expands:

1853




1992 edition:

Adds 25 Assorted yellow tiles to the game.

4 × #3
4 × #4
1 × #71
2 × #72
3 × #73
2 × #74
1 × #75
1 × #76
1 × #77
3 × #78
2 × #79
1 × #113

1999 edition:

Adds 16 Assorted yellow tiles to the game.

From the Sheet that comes with it:
This Kit consists of 16 extra yellow track titles that may be added to the standard game. This increases the number of tiles that are available for the development of new areas of the board and is particularly useful to those who like to lay a lot of metre gauge track.

Includes the following tracks:
2 × #3
2 × #4
2 × #73
2 × #75
1 × #113
1 × #71
1 × #72
2 × #76
3 × #78
38260.name: MIK 1 Extension Kit for 1853

38261.description:
Washington DC and Berlin are another pair of Age of Steam maps created by highly regarded Age of Steam expansion designer Alban Viard.

Washington DC focuses on the infamous freeways of the US capital. While the interstate can allow for quick goods transportation, it also becomes increasingly clogged as the game progresses and eventually becomes nearly impassable.

The Berlin Wall, meanwhile, takes Age of Steam back to the era of the Cold War and the divided city of Berlin. Troop garrisons impede goods movement for much of the game, and the wall also presents an imposing obstacle. Of course, the fall of the wall in 1989 changes everything.

The Berlin Wall map was reprinted in 2011 as part of Age of Steam Expansion: Moon and Berlin Wall.
38261.name: Age of Steam Expansion: Washington DC and The Berlin Wall

38263.description:
From the publisher:
"Some of the Chinese characters regarding fish and shellfish are made up of two parts, left meaning "fish" and right showing characteristics of fish and shellfish. This is a card game which matches the left and right of the Chinese character and fish-shellfish pictures. Randomly disperse the cards on a table face down and turn over two cards. It is pleasurable to match correctly a fish picture and/or Chinese character in the left corner of the card. The Sushi corresponds to each of 29 fish-shellfish that are illustrated. The 29 fish and shellfish chosen are commonly served in Sushi bars.
There are 3 cards in the pack which have no fish or shellfish, but are generally found in Sushi bars. Card-A : soy sauce dipping dish and its pot. Card-B : a cup of hot green tea, called "AGARI", and tea pot. Card-C : hot Sake bottle "TTOKURI" and tiny cup "CHOKO". When playing the game, these cards give you a lucky chance, by way of an extra turn.
The pictures were made by cutting the Japanese gaily-colored pieces of paper, "Chiyogami"."
38263.name: Sushi Bar

38264.name: Politrix
38264.description:
"All the excitement and drama of the Presidential Campaign is captured in this unique new game for the 80's. Politrix combines the skill and strategy of Presidential Politics with humor & fun!! Race against opposition as you raise funds, buy votes, and form party tickets on the way to becoming President of the United States."

Basic roll-and-move with three circular tracks: fundraising, campaigning, and the election. The "unique" aspect of the game is that when players move into the middle (campaigning) track they must declare a political party (Democan or Republicrat) and only one player of each party may advance to the inner (election) as that party's nominee.

The game comes with: a board, 6 plastic tokens, two-page rules, 2 six-sided dice, scorepad, two sets of ballots (33 Democan & 33 Republicrat, 6 @ 50 votes & 27 @ 100 votes each), two event decks (25 "Campaign Strategy" cards and 40 "Between the Headlines" cards), paper money, and a "33rpm recording vital to your campaign" with strategy hints.

38265.name: Liberty March
38265.description:
"Liberty March" covers the battle of August 6, 1777 in which British and Indian forces ambushed a column of American militia at Oriskany in the Mohawk Valley in New York. The game is "For 2 to 8 players, Ages 12 and up" allowing players to "re-enact the bloodiest battle of the American Revolution."
Game was apparently produced in a "Limited First Edition" of 500 copies. Game came in a thin, white cardboard box with an unmounted cardboard hex map of the battlefield; a circa 10 page rulebook; x2 1D10; one sheet of thin, blue and pink colored cardboard unit counters; and an Historical Guide.

38266.description:
Kriegbot, the future of robotic combat vehicles. Secretly outfit your robot with weapons like railguns, EMP blasters, and chainsaws. Add a couple of systems like targeting computers, incendiary munitions, or radar. Mount all of this hardware on a unique chassis, like a hovercraft or a helicopter, and then team up and battle it out with other kriegbots on a tactical terrain map.
Kriegbot is a game for 2 to 6 players, which takes an hour or two to play. It is designed by Matt Eklund of Sierra Madre Games. It comes with rules and technology background, 6 plastic robot figures, 40 plastic markers, 92 color design cards, 6 color vehicle templates, 3 special dice, and 1 color map.
38266.name: Kriegbot

38267.name: Dados
38267.description: Dados is a dice game for 2-4 players. Each player gets 36 dice, which are rolled 4 at a time and placed on 18 tiles. Each turn, a player can choose to either roll the dice, placing one die on four separate tiles, or to pick up one contested tile where he/she the higher total pip count, earning points based on what is written on the bottom of the coaster (generally related to the combined value of the dice from all players). The game ends when both players run out of dice. There are also special coasters that do not earn points, but instead offer one-off powers, such as "put two dice on a single coaster".

38268.name: Two Lobster Dice Games
38268.description:
This game comes as five dice packaged in a tube with a short page of game rules. The ones on the dice are replaced with lobsters.

In the first game (just called "A Lobster Dice Game") players must successfully molt their lobsters by rolling the dice. Unsuccessful players are out of the game, and the last lobster to molt is declared largest and wins.

In the second game ("Lobster Fishing") the players score one point for each lobster of legal size caught (i.e., a lobster rolled along with a 4, 5 or 6.) After 10 rounds of fishing, the winner is the one who caught the most lobsters legally.

38269.name: Lingo Foly's
38269.description:
A language trivia game for 1 to 4 teams (min 1 player per team) to recognize English, German, French, and Spanish phrases.

Game is in French.

38270.name: 2D-Pachisi
38270.description:
2D-Pachisi is, like the name implies, a variant of the original Pachisi/Ludo/Mensch ärger dich nicht.
For a 4 player version you need a board of 9×9 squares; for the 6 player version, a hex field of 9 hexes in diameter.
In both, you start at the center of the board and use the dice to determine the direction and the number of fields you can go. As in Ludo, 2 game pieces are not allowed in the same spot, so the last piece entering the spot remains, the other one goes back to the center. Goal is to reach the color corresponding corner of the board with all 4 of you game pieces.

38272.name: C-TEC-OPOLY
38272.description:
C-TEC-OPOLY

First Edition (c)1996

Pride Distributors

A monopoly game created for the C-TEC Corporation, a telecommunications company. Spaces shown on the board include the Mercer County Airport, C-TEC Corporate Headquarters, MEGACABLE, Residential Communications Network, etc.

38273.description:
This Trivial Pursuit edition is about 60´s & 70´s years

The mechanics of the game are similar to other Trivial Pursuit games, but questions are about the things that happened in this years (music, movies, tv programs, famous people...)

The game is in Spanish. The box has 1000 question and answer Cards
38273.name: Trivial Pursuit: Edición Jóvenes Carrozas

38274.name: Fädelzoo
38274.description:
Fädelzoo (Threading Zoo) is a collection of four games all based on the concept of threading pieces onto or off of a string. The theme is animals in a zoo -- the animals have discovered a new favorite past time, which is to connect all of the zoo inhabitants in a line. They first group the animals together by type (all the penguins, then the elephants..), then link the groups together.

Three of the games are interactive and one of these is cooperative. One is to match the threading to a picture (many pictures for this are included), another is a race to complete the threading first but pieces are only added when the right die roll is thrown, and the third is to cooperatively build a single thread as fast as possible. The fourth activity in the box is a solitaire exercise.

38275.description:
Three robots are on the game board in Robotory, and to win a player must have at least two robots on their side of the game board when the supply cubes of one color are exhausted. On a turn, a player either places a cube of either color from their personal supply onto the game board, takes cubes from the supply, or moves a robot; to move, a robot "eats" cubes of the appropriate color, with two of the robots eating cubes of only one color and the third robot eating cubes of both colors.

The 2015 edition of the game, PakuPakuPark, replaces the robots in a factory with animals on a farm, with the dog eating ham, the cat eating fish, and the pig eating both foods.
38275.name: Robotory

38276.name: Wildfire

7218.name: Roosevelt Center for American Policy Studies

38276.description:
WILDFIRE is a two move role-playing game that acquaints players with the problems associated with the spread of nuclear weapons and some of the solutions to these problems. The basic WILDFIRE game is designed to be played either in two 45-minute sessions of one move each or in a single 90-minute session with a short break between moves. A short introductory exercise is designed to be worked through in advance.

The game has three separate parts- an introductory exercise and two "moves". The introductory exercise covers the fundamentals of the problem and some basic facts (like who has nuclear arsenals today) and gets players thinking about the overall issue. The first move is a crisis control exercise in which players take on the roles of top officials in five nations that are wrestling with a future nuclear crisis involving India and Pakistan. The second and final move is a post-crisis negotiation exercise in which players seek a long-term solution to the conflict between India and Pakistan,

38277.name: Impact
38277.description:
An example of the family oriented, large-box dexterity games of the 60s & 70s, the object of Impact is to knock a steel ball off a rail by swinging a weighted pendulum across the ball’s path, thereby knocking the ball into scoring compartments.

The box includes: Plastic playing base; Metal rail; Score-markers; lower legs w/arch support; Upper arm; Upper arm swivel; Chain w/weight; steel ball

An arcing metal rail sits atop a tray of numbered compartments which serve as the score area. Each player is given 10 plastic score-markers for tallying. A player sets the steel ball at one end of the rail and releases it. Timing a swing of the pendulum, the other player attempts to knock the ball off the rail and into one of the scoring areas marked 100, 200, 500. If the player misses, the other player attempts to catch the pendulum and, if successful, can take a shot at scoring as well.

Play continues until someone scores, in which case the scoring player sets the ball in action again, or until the ball stops rolling, in which case the original “roller” sets the ball on its path again.

The game is over when either player has placed all 10 markers and the scores are tallied.

Impact was released in 1971. Interestingly, the game Balanko http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/23728 , winner of the “Family Fun” award in 2007, appears to be a direct “descendant” of this game, with the designer claiming to have invented the game in his garage. A quote from his site states, with irony that may be intentional or not: “Upon tinkering around in the garage one day with his son, Jamie began to build a game without any knowing of how this game would one day strongly impact his life.”

38278.name: The Big Board
38278.description:
Released toward the end of the Great Depression in 1937, The Big Board, like many games released during this time frame, reflects an America, and the world, pulling itself out of economic chaos. The lure of trading large sums of cash with the possibility of striking it rich ran deep in the collective unconscious across the globe.

The box includes 835 shares of stock in each of nine different corporations with the following denominations/counts: 1/10, 5/5, 10/5, 50/5, 100/5. This is at odds with the instructions which call for 435 shares. It also includes approximately $110,000 in paper money in the following denominations: $5, $10, $20, $50, $100, $1,000 and $5,000. Again this is at odds with the instructions which call for $147,600. Included is one pair of standard dice, a dice cup, 9 wooden Price markers, and one large board marking the rising stock prices.

The Big Board “represents the quotation board as used in a broker’s office”, and attempts to “represent in a realistic manner the fluctuation of stocks, as on the New York Stock Exchange.” Nine stocks are available for trading. Each player starts with $5,000.00. One player is selected as the supervisor of the treasury and stock certificates. The instructions suggest that this player throws the dice and moves the price quotation markers, but is “not the banker and does not participate in the profits or losses of the BIG BOARD.”, effectively removing the player from the game. For those who don’t wish to be left out of the game, an easy house rule could fix this by allowing one person to be banker and perhaps shifting the throw of the dice from player to player.

The game begins with the price markers on each of the stock spaces marked PAR. The market is now open and all players may purchase one or more shares of as many stocks as they wish. The dice are then rolled for the first stock, with the operator moving the marker upward the matching number of spaces rolled. If the marker lands on a value space, the price is set, if it lands on a “Down To” space, it is moved to the corresponding lower value and the price is set there. Players may now buy or sell values of this stock. These phases are continued for each stock, with the dice returning to the first stock when the others have been set. During intervals, transactions can occur at the current price of any stock.

The game can end in several ways: at a set time determined by all players at the start of the game (suggested by the game designers as a more realistic simulation of stock activity from day to day), or when 1 player has lost all money or the treasury is exhausted, or even when 1 player has made a “certain amount of money over and above that which he started with”.

38279.name: Spin and Spell Word Making Game
38279.description: Spin the dial! Collect letters! See who can make the most words!

38280.name: I Spy Mouse Follies
38280.description: Players race against time to find the objects cleverly hidden in colourful illustrations that match the pictures on each card drawn. The player who collects the most cards is the winner. The game includes 6 game boards and 50 different object cards.

38281.description:
Le Peuple Paille (the hay people) are participating in the challenges of the Celtic tribes are playing for the honour of the Dame Bleue. They go to the side of the victorious ones and help name the supreme winner.
But in these fairy lands, a lot of things are happening: friendly dances, holy rites, terrifying apparitions of the "burner"...
In order to face those new challenges, you have to be opportunistic and you have to get 'the hay people' to admire you in order to win !

This is an expansion to the Dame Bleue game.
38281.name: Peuple Paille

38282.description:
First expansion to Okko: Era of the Asagiri that adds the Yakuza mafia as mercenaries and includes:

9 new characters and their profile cards
-Ashigaru with Tsukubo
-Fire eater
-Henchman
-Kunoishi
-Apprentice thief
-Oyabun Akachi
-Chained ogre
-Ninja
-Corrupt magistrate

5 equipment cards including:
-Shuriken
-Tatoos
-Smokescreen
-Red Algae
38282.name: Okko, Yakuza Hazu Akai

38284.name: Wild Jacks
38284.description: A Pente variant in which a hand of cards determines where you can place chips. Object is to get 2 lines of 5 on the board.

38285.name: Last Step Game
38285.description:
A simple abstract NIM game on a 5x5 board. Players start by alternately placing the shared pieces on the board, and then alternately moving the pieces E, SE, S, or SW. Last player to move loses.

Includes dozens of variants for pieces with different movement rules, win conditions, and a larger board on the flip side.

38286.description:
Game description from the publisher:

The Solomons Campaign is an extensive redesign of the old-SPI game of the same name originally designed and published by James F. Dunnigan in 1973. It presents a two-player, complex historical simulation of the air, sea and land campaigns waged on and around the island of Guadalcanal in the summer and fall of 1942. The game begins with the American invasion of that island and includes the subsequent Japanese attempts to retake it. The game is intended to be a simulation of combined air-naval-ground operations, or what are today called "joint operations". Consequently it centers on modeling command and staff systems, focusing on the difficulties and advantages inherent in sequenced interactions between and among air, naval and ground forces.
38286.name: The Solomons Campaign (second edition)

boardgamehonor.19816: 2011/2012 Boardgames Australia Awards Best Children's Game Nominee

38287.description:
Beep! Beep! Is a fast paced game of driving through a forest and swerving to miss the wildlife.
The game consists of a small rubber squeaky car and 112 cards each with an animal in a particular color on it. Players simultaneously try to match either the animal OR the color to those they have already avoided. When three of the same color or animal appear at the same time, hit the squeaky car to Beep! Beep! your horn and get them out of the way.
The player who avoids the most animals wins.

Publisher blurb:

Save the animals from the squeaky red car! Collect matching animals or colors, and be quick, because you all act at the same time! But take care to see whether in the middle of the table there are three identical animals or colors - then quickly squeeze the red car and win bonus points. Who can save the most animals and squeeze the most bonus points wins the game.
38287.name: Beep! Beep!

38288.name: Gamushara gang
38288.description:
Translated from the box back:

Story
The wildest gang in the world: The Gamushara Gang.
One day, the boss suddenly announces his retirement! Who will be the next boss!? The race for the boss's seat begins!
And in the middle of this chaos, one rumor starts… "There is a spy in the Gamushara Gang!!" Who is the spy!? And who will stand as the next boss!?
Will you fool the others, or be fooled? A blood-boiling game is about to begin!

Game
In this game, the players take the role of a gang member, and competes against them. They will be eliminated one by one, and the last player standing is the winner.
(But there is a spy among them, so don't be fooled!!)

A psychological game of guessing, bluffing and gambling that can make anyone suspicious about everything!

Illustrated by Toshinobu Kondo

38289.name: Multi
38289.description:
From the editor:
Move as in "Chinese Checkers" trying to score as many points as possible by occupying your opponents most important positions with your most valuable counters.

38290.name: He Lücht (Die fröhliche Hafenrundfahrt)
38290.description:
The game is called "He Lücht", translated this means "he's lying".

Each player rolls a die and moves around the game map (which depicts the Hamburg harbour). On special spaces he may ask a real or a "He Lücht" question.
If he can answer the question he may move on.
Some special events happen if the player moves on defined spaces.
The player who reaches the last space is the winner.

38291.name: Loser's Game
38291.description:
Loser’s Game is a relatively simple trick-taking game for three to four players. Your goal is to end each round with 3 of a kind and 4 of a kind in the cards you took. The twist in this game is that it blatantly favors the underdog; the player with the lowest score at the start of each hand gets to choose what suit is trump.

All you need is a Poker deck (Jokers removed) to play.

38292.name: High Noon
38292.description:
High Noon is an intense one-on-one memory game. On your turn, you can add a card to the stare down or gather the cards up and call “Draw!” If you draw, your opponent must recite the cards in the stare down from first played to last played. If your opponent succeeds, he or she gets the cards. If your opponent fails, you get the cards. The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

High Noon uses a deck of cards (any kind of cards will do). A two-player game takes 5 to 10 minutes to play. High Noon is appropriate for almost any age, but matched ages are better.

38293.name: The Unnamed Game
38293.description:
The Unnamed Game is a game with three distinct, recurring phases (resource gathering, trading, and creation) for three to five players.

During resource gathering, you play a trick-taking game against your opponents. During the trick-taking game, each of you has a unique special power you can use to bend the rules of the game, but when one special power activates, any other active one goes away.

You’ll trade the cards you accumulate during the first phase and use them to purchase special one-shot FX in the trading phase.

Any cards you have left over at the start of the creation phase turn into action tokens. You use action tokens to gather workers and to have your workers build creations. You can also use the FX you purchased in phase two to help your workers. The game ends when a player has five or more creations at the end of the third phase. If you have the most creations at the end of the game, you win.

The Unnamed Game requires a Special Powers deck, an FX deck, a Creation Tracker. You can download these from the publisher. You’ll also need to provide a Poker deck, about 5 six-sided dice per player, a unique pawn for each player, a totem, and about 30 tokens.

A three-player game takes about 40 minutes to play. The Unnamed Game’s unusual structure and strategic nature probably makes it appropriate for ages 14 and older.

38294.name: Whakka Mole
38294.description:
Whakka Mole is a game of bluffing and brinkmanship for two people looking to vent a little aggression. Each turn you get to select which moles pop out of your mole holes while selecting one of your opponents’ holes to whack. You get points for whacking your opponent’s moles, and by keeping your moles from being whacked.

Whakka Mole uses about 10 tokens per player, a custom sheet that you can download from http://www.invisible-city.com/play/404 , and pencil and paper. A two-player game takes 5 to 10 minutes to play. Whakka Mole is appropriate for Ages 10 and up.

38295.name: Foray!
38295.description:
The gameboard is a 15 x 6 grid. Each player's territory consists of the last six rows opposite the opponent. Each player places one's own six playing pieces according to the diagram in the rules.

To win the game a player must capture all the opponent's playing pieces by landing on them thereby capturing them or score five points by penetrating the opponent's territory with one's own piece and returning.

On one's turn, one rolls two-four sided dice and moves one playing piece. A player moves one piece orthogonally and is allowed only one ninety degree turn. A player may U-turn only after penetrating the opponent's territory.

Re-released as:

Ninja Versus Ninja

38296.name: Between the Lions Comedy Story Shaker
38296.description: Between the Lions is an educational childrens' program on PBS designed to promote reading. This is a small game intended for children included with kids' meals from Chick-Fil-A. 18 Small chits are inserted into a small faux-book. Each chit displays a picture of an object, such as "big toe" or "umbrella." The book is shaken, and then three of the chits are removed. The player whose turn it is then has to tell a story involving each of the three pictures. The method for scoring is clearly not the point of the game, which is educational, but involves counting the consonants on each of the chits.

38297.description: 1898 is an 18xx game set in France. It is a non-historical variant of 1841. Only 100 Copies were produced.

38298.name: 18HeXX
38298.description: Fictional/Variable Map System for 18xx. Large Groups of Hexes in cutouts.

38299.description:
On the morning of 24 December 1806, the Russian troops of Major General Ivan Semenovich Dorokhov waited at Borkowo for the expected French attack under Klein and Lasalle.

SYSTEM: "Jours de Gloire" Series (JdG)
- scale = 297 m/hex;
- time = 75 min/GT;
- strength = 200 men/SP.
38299.name: Borkowo 1806

38300.name: Minarett
38300.description: Players try to build towers (Minaretts) using the wooden pieces. A chess-like set of rules define where pieces may be placed, moved, or captured. The game is won by either capturing 3 opposing pieces, or by creating a Minarett of entirely one color.

38301.description:
This wargame is issued in Vae Victis 82.

It simulates the Red army (2nd Ukrainian front) offensives on Iasi and Târgu-Frumos (Romania, April and May 1944).

This game is using the same game system as Korsoun 1944 and Alsace 1944 .
38301.name: Târgu-Frumos 1944

38302.description:
Just like in the original Tetris, the players attempt to place the game pieces on the board with the object of forming complete rows. The roll of a die determines which piece you have to play onto the gameboard.

Special formations grant bonus points. When the game pieces are used up, the player with the highest score wins.

According to the publisher it's a simple, but strategic block game in the Tetris family.
38302.name: Tetris Duel

38304.description: An 18xx game set in the Hiroshima metropolitan area of Japan. Designed and published by Toryo Hojo (also reportedly by Masanaga Hojo). Utilizes tiles from 1856.

38305.name: Comprendo!
38305.description:
Now there's an easy way for all the family to speak Spanish while having fun.

Going to Spain? Play Comprendo!® the board game, and you'll soon be getting by effortlessly in the language!

This fast and fun family game simulates a holiday in Spain.

You don't need to know any Spanish beforehand – but you do need your wits about you!

By speaking Spanish words and phrases you collect day trips. The first person to match these day trips to their original 'wish list' wins.

You don't need any Spanish to play. The questions in Comprendo!® are specially constructed with clues so that even complete beginners can answer them. All the Spanish has an intuitive pronunciation guide. Playing Comprendo!® is not like being in a classroom. There's no grammar or exercises. You pick the language up unconsciously, by hearing and speaking. It's a friendly, fast-moving family game, and making the odd mistake is all part of the fun!

-- http://www.comprendogame.com

38306.description:
War Storm Series presents a free A las Barricadas! module, La Guerra del Rif (1920-1926) (The Rif War).

In this first print & Play free module, we try to represent the special characteristics of this unknown war. Some special rules change the A las Barricadas! v2 engine. This first scenario includes one overlay, 71 new counters, specific rules and a ammo chart.
38306.name: La Guerra del Rif

38309.description:
The game is set in Poland and draws heavily from the book by Norman Davies. It covers the period from about 1400 to 1790, which is covered by vol 1 of the two books.

Each player represents a Polish magnate. There are various ways of scoring victory points, owning land, religious activity, winning battles, etc. Surrounding Poland are her numerous enemies, who may or may not decide to attack Poland. It is up to the players how well they defend the country. The way the enemies work is that they change their strength to match historical changes.
38309.name: God's Playground

38311.description: An 18xx game. Map covers: Gunma, Tochigi, and Saitama prefectures, Japan
38311.name: 1897Medium

38312.description: An 18xx game. Map covers: Northern Kanto area, Japan
38312.name: 1897Large

38313.description: An 18xx game set in the Northern Kanto Plains of Japan. Game map covers: Gunma prefecture.

38314.name: Planet der Sinne: Hören

boardgamefamily.19020: HABA Planet der Sinne (Sensory Planet) series

38314.description:
In 2007, Haba released a game called Planet der Sinne (Sensory Planet) that includes a range of games to teach children about the different senses. This game is an expansion, sort of anyway. It is all about the sense of hearing, and some of the games and exercises are used in the original Planet der Sinne but some are new.

The box is jammed with componentsto play over a dozen games, all sounds as the idea. Compments includes various bells, clickers, sticks, a board, and a blindfold. Some are just exercises, while others are fun games that work for the family.

38315.name: Planet der Sinne: Sehen

boardgamefamily.19020: HABA Planet der Sinne (Sensory Planet) series

38315.description:
In 2007, Haba released a game called Planet der Sinne (Sensory Planet) that includes a range of games to teach children about the different senses. This game is an expansion, sort of anyway. It is all about the sense of sight, and some of the games and exercises are used in the original Planet der Sinne but some are new.

The box is jammed with components to play over a dozen games, all using visual clues and observation as the idea. Some are just exercises, while others are fun games that work for the family.

38316.description:
The game explores the past, present, and future of the Arab/Israeli struggle. Includes a 56 page booklet focused on the history behind (and yet to come of) the game. The game is based on the Advanced Millennium Wars system, incorporating asymmetric situations, non-state actors, and political constraints. The game scale is 10km per hex, units are brigades or divisions, or cadres/groups.

Scenarios included in the game:
1. '48 War Phase 1
2. '48 War Phase 2
3. '67 War
4. '67 War Jihad (What if)
5. ‘73 War
6. ’82 Lebanon War
7. ’06 Military Solution in Southern Lebanon
8. '12 Hypothetical

The Advanced Millennium Wars system is quite unique relative to traditional wargame designs. Rather than utilize quantitative "factors" for such things as movement and combat, the game is entirely missions based, with each unit being capable of performing a given set of missions as indicated by icons on the backs of the unit counters. Missions are combined into Operations against specific targets, which can include other units in play, populations centers on the map, or political capital. Targets on the receiving end of such operations must execute specific casualty chains to account for losses caused by offensive operations. The game also utilizes a unique "Tier" system that determines the number of phases the units of any given faction may conduct missions per turn.
38316.name: Millennium Wars Advanced: The Lebanon Scenarios

38317.name: ChampionChip
38317.description:
This game can only be played while you and your friends are watching a football match (preferably on television).

Every player has his own set of coloured chips he uses to place bets on the the playing mat before or during the match.

Bets include:
- team to score first goal
- end result
- who'll get a yellow/red card first
- who scores the goals
- which team spits on the pitch first
- ...

Depending on the difficulty level of the bet you get payed by the bank and by the other players who lost the bet.

boardgameimplementation.24996: Start Player: A Kinda Collectible Card Game

38318.description:
Game description from the publisher:

By our detailed calculations, more than 2.5 million additional games could be played each year if you took less time picking a start player. Start Player solves this problem: Just turn over a card and you'll know who the start player is. Maybe it's as simple as identifying the tallest player, or the player with the most unbuttoned buttons. It's the most comprehensive system ever devised for choosing who starts a game.
38318.name: Start Player

38319.name: RNtertainment: An Nclex Review Board Game
38319.description:
See if you have what it takes to be a Nurse. Roll the dice and the color you land on determines what kind of question you are asked. Beware of "Code Black and Blue" cards that set you back. Move forward faster with "Healthy Rewards" cards. The "healthiest player" (first one to the finish) wins.

Contents:

Game board
Die
6 player pieces
25 Healthy Rewards cards
25 Code Black & Blue cards
75 Medication cards
75 Disease Process/Anatomy & Physiology cards
75 Patient Care cards
75 Diagnostic Testing cards

38320.description:
The Mediterranean Theater Expansion introduces British Army figures and rules to the Memoir '44 game system, as well as a whole new class of Special Weapon Assets to embed in infantry units. Also included are eight new historical scenarios in North Africa, 44 new, double-sided Terrain tiles, plus new obstacles, markers, and special-forces badges.

Part of the Memoir '44 series.

Expands:

Memoir '44
38320.name: Memoir '44: Mediterranean Theater

38321.name: The Defence of Duffer's Drift
38321.description:
Lt. Backsight Forethought has been left at Duffer's Drift with a simple task. Prevent a Boer detachment from crossing the river. He has 50 men, good and brave, to do the deed. Through a series of dreams he goes from failure to success. Play the game and you will learn as well.

The Defence of Duffer's Drift is a war game with role-playing elements based on Chris' Engle's Encounter Matrix Game rules. The game includes a reprint of Captain E. D. Swindon's book, a classic of Boer War strategy (Swindon went on to serve as a Major General in World War I).

The game board and pieces are hand-made and include the maps from Swindon's book.

From the box:
ROLEPLAYING: Good
COMPLEXITY: High
SOLO PLAY: Fair

38322.name: Suit Yourself
38322.description:
Suit Yourself was published in A Gamut of Games. It is based in the family of games played with matches know as Nim games.

Nim games are know to be easily mathematically studied and a player who has done it will always win one who does not have. Suit Yourself, using a deck of cards instead of matches, lead to a different starting position of the game in each play, so that this advantage disappears.

The deck of cards is distributted in five collumns, two with eleven cards and three with ten cards each. In each turn, a player can take as many cards are on top of the collums as he wishes, but all must be from the same suit. When all cards are taken, the player with most cards in his hands is the winner.

38323.description:
This expansion offers you to play Super Vache (Super cow) up to 6 players now. There are new fields, new powers for your cow, new "coup-fourré".

Expands:

Super Vache
38323.name: Super Vache L'extension

38324.name: Finger Twister Game
38324.description:
This is a game in Daiso's Joint Party Series of games.
Players place their figures on a small board according to the outcome of spinning a special spinner, which indicates a spscific colour and the finger which must be used to touch a spot with that colour on the board.
Players who are unable to do so lose.

This is a different game from the game called 'Finger Twister' in the BGG database. This game uses all five fingers (unlike Finger Twister) and the board has a different arrangement of spots and also includes special spots known as 'breathless points'.

The instruction under 'breathless point':
"You can touch whom you are interested in through the delicate balance position! Sometimes physical contact bring people together."

However, there's also a caution on the label: "Please note that this game doesn't always let boy meets girl."

38325.name: Prezyun Breake
38325.description:
Translated from the manual:

A prison. It's where the shit jerks who did too much are put.
A place where the rats who were either stupid or clumsy are kept separated from society until they cool down.
No one, no matter how crazy, wants to go there.
But there was one complete idiot who ended up in the special prison for violent maniacs.
...and that's you.

It's defended by a system that Alcatraz or Bastilles don't come near. A huge hell, finely constructed and full of patrols.
If you can get out of there, the next thing and you'll be able to break of out Hell itself.
Even so, this is your line:
"So what. I have to do it."
You have to, to save the guy on death roll, who was innocently judged.
Use your skill, your genius and your brains to the fullest.
What awaits you is unimportant. Your must save the man, get him out of there, think tactically, and use whatever tools you can get ahold of.
Got it? Good. Let's get going.

38326.name: Talisman Upgrade Pack
38326.description:
Upgrade Your Game!

The Talisman Upgrade Pack allows owners of Talisman 4th Edition published by Black Industries to replace the cards and characters of that edition with updated components from the Talisman (Revised 4th Edition), published by Fantasy Flight Games. This will make their Talisman game compatible with new Talisman expansions for the Revised 4th Edition.

This Upgrade Pack is an affordable solution for players who have already purchased Talisman 4th Edition and want the improved game components and expandability of the Talisman (Revised 4th Edition).

Don your armour and sharpen your sword. A world of adventure awaits!

38327.description:
Contents: a board with the drawing of a circuit with circles and rabbit holes. 8 rabbit pawns. 36 carrot pawns. 2 dices.

The goal of the game is to be the first to pass the arrival line.

Each player chooses a rabbit, and receive 5 carrots. Rabbit move accordingly to the result of the dices thrown. One can choose to throw one or two dices, in the latter case he must pay a carrot (if he makes a double with the dices, he get his carrot back). The circuit have special circles such as “carrot”, “coyote”, blue or pink circles, each with special actions to be make.
38327.name: Le lapin malin

38328.description: The Looney Bin is a deduction game with fast action - reaction card play that depicts the uproarious occurrences of an insane asylum. The object is to be the first to heal all the patients in your ward by treatment with various therapies. Non phasing player action ability keeps everyone involved for very little down time. Contains 35 patients, 90 staff and action cards, 35 symptom tiles and plenty of therapy chits.
38328.name: The Looney Bin

38329.description:
The battle of Las Navas of Tolosa has passed to history as the biggest defeat of the Almohade army during the Reconquista in Spain, we are going to see all the details of the battle.

La Batalla de Las Navas de Tolosa ha pasado a la historia como la mayor derrota del ejército Almohade durante la Reconquista, vamos a ver los detalles de la batalla.
38329.name: La Batalla de las Navas de Tolosa

38330.description:
Quäsenbö is a card game for the Decktet. It is similar to standard-deck Crazy Eights, but is, however, somewhat more complex due to the multiple-suit nature of the Decktet cards, and because the third consecutive play of the same suit is penalized by having to draw an extra card.

The author makes the historically dubious claim that "Quäsenbö was a popular game at the court of the badger Charlemagne. Its name means 'too many.' The theme is thought to reflect political issues of royal succession in the many small kingdoms of the Empire; although some feminist historians believe it instead derives from the quäsenbö pan, a cast-iron skillet capable of turning out vast numbers of spätzle at a time."
38330.name: Quäsenbö

38331.description:
A tactical game
The cows have been the whole day outside the stable and must return to it. The players try to get their own herd asap in the stable. The first player to manage this wins the game. Players use movement and action cards to move the cows and to shove each other into the cowpats that are on their way.

Game for 2-4 players!
Game box consists of
16 cow meeples in 4 different colours.
4 decks of 29 movement cards each
4 playing mats (printed both sides)
38331.name: Fiese Kühe

38332.name: Death at Samarra
38332.description:
In Death at Samarra, you must protect your Servant while stalking your opponent's pieces. But which piece is his Servant, and which is Death? Your Merchant can reveal another piece's identity, but in doing so, unmasks himself.

This two-player game of bluffing and hidden strategy plays quickly, but uniquely each time. How well can you outguess the person across the table?

Download the two-page black-and-white PDF DeathSamarra_ed1.pdf at the Files Section, print and assemble it in 15 minutes, and play several 3-8 minute games with a friend tonight.

38333.name: Kapitú
38333.description:
A Trivia type of game, played in teams (2 to 4 teams - 8 max. per team).

The goal of the game is to name the maximum correct answers in one minute. Sample questions are: "In one minute name all the birds you know, for example seagull". Team members start, in order, naming birds. If one of the members repeats an answer or makes a mistake, the teams loses and only the previous answers count.

The board is used to advance in difficulty, and the game ends when the first team reaches the final box. Corrects answers are then added and the team with the highest score wins.

38334.description:
Publisher's description of this new hex-tile game scheduled to debut at Essen 2008:

"Logan Stones is a two player strategic game that encourages memory and tactical thinking. It is played without a board, using 18 tactile pieces that are etched and painted on both sides with different symbols.

The game has simple rules that are based on the visually recognizable symbols of Rock Paper Scissors.

Logan Stones takes the simplicity of ‘Rock Paper Scissors’ and adds to it a fast paced, fun game, that can also be played with strategic precision for a much more thought provoking experience. The aim is to make a line of 4 of the same symbol, but as you and your opponent are in control of the same stones and with them constantly being flipped over to reveal new symbols, it’s not as simple as it sounds."
38334.name: Logan Stones

38335.description:
An 18xx game set in the Osaka metropolitan area of Japan.

Rules are available as Wiki at http://www.boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/1890_English_Rules

38336.name: 1899KP
38336.description: An 18xx title that covers the Korean Peninsula

38337.description:
In this twisted take on Go Fish, you fight against terrorism as the heroic head of a government agency. You must utilize cunning, connections, wire taps and covert ops to hunt down and capture the likes of the Cultists of Invincible Anarchy, the Gun Toting Maniacs and the Militant Satanic Gamers.
Don't worry though, you're not alone. Your “friends” are heads of their own agencies, and they're also trying to capture terrorists. Of course, whoever captures the most terrorists will get a Presidential commendation, a significant budget increase and win the game!

Fishing for Terrorists Version 2.0 has all new color art and more strategic game play.
38337.name: Fishing for Terrorists Version 2.0

38338.name: Tumble Logs
38338.description:
From the box: "Stack your logs on the pile in 45 seconds without letting any of them tumble and you score!"

The game includes three dice, a 45-second sand timer, and wooden "logs" of three different sizes and colors. On a player's turn, they roll the three dice. The color and number of each die tells how many logs of each color must be added to the stack. The player has 45 seconds to add them without wrecking the stack or having any logs roll off.

38339.name: Història Màgica de Catalunya
38339.description:
[EN]: A simple fantasy-medieval game in which the player must travel around Western Mediterranean cities (specially Catalan ones) with the ultimate aim of dueling with and defeating a mythological dragon. During the travel, the player gets cards in each city he passes, and these cards drive the game, as they contain events, missions, travels and so on, which can improve the player's powers until he or she is ready to fight the dragon.

---

[CA]: Un joc simple de temàtica fantàstica-medieval, en què el jugador ha de viatjar per diverses ciutats de la Mediterrània occidental (especialment catalanes) amb l'objectiu final de lluitar i véncer un drac mitològic. Durant el viatge el jugador rep cartes a cada ciutat per la qual passa i aquestes cartes dirigeixen el joc, ja que contenen esdeveniments, missions que cal complir, viatges, etc. i permeten millorar les característiques del jugador fins que està llest per lluitar amb el drac.

---

[ES]: Un sencillo juego de tema fantástico-medieval, en el cual el jugador tiene que viajar por diversas ciudades del Mediterráneo occidental (especialmente catalanas) con el objetivo final de luchar y derrotar a un dragón mitológico. Durante el viaje el jugador recibe cartas en cada ciudad por la que pasa y estas cartas dirigen el juego porque contienen eventos, misiones que hay que cumplir, viajes, etc. y permiten mejorar las características del jugador hasta que está listo para luchar contra el dragón.

38340.name: Scene It? Seinfeld
38340.description:
From the Publisher:

Man hands, Manssieres, Yo-Yo Ma, and Yada Yada Yada-Scene It? Seinfeld Edition has everything you love from the show about nothing. Race around the Flextime game board as you relive your favorite Seinfeld moments and test your knowledge with on-screen puzzlers more challenging than the Festivus feats of strength. We opened The Vault to include classic clips from all nine seasons and enough trivia to keep you double dipping!

Game Includes:

* Collectible Tin (Deluxe edition only)
* 1 DVD
* Flextime® Game Board
* Party Play
* 4 Collectible Metal Tokens
* 175 Trivia Cards
* 16 Buzz Cards
* 1 Six-Sided Die
* 1 Eight-Sided Die
* Set of Game Rules

38341.name: Game of RIO
38341.description:
RIO is a fast paced, light family card game which acts superbly as a filler.

What makes the game special is that it comes in the Parker Brothers standard box size of its time, same as e.g. Star Reporter.
Thus it is completely oversized, but if it's your cup of tea you are rewarded during gameplay by excellent graphics on the board and the box inlays where holiday scenes are depicted.

Game consists of 48 cards - 4 sets of 12 numbers in 4 colours - which have to be laid out in a given pattern onto the board where a kind of discard-clock is shown.

In order to win you have to get rid of your cards before all other players.

You can score in different ways, and you have to decide when it's the best time to lay out your own or to destroy opponents winning combination and when to exchange cards of your hand with pre-dealt cards on the clock.

Although the rules state that 3 to 6 can play it also works well with 2 players, and there are variants for partnership play.

38343.description:
Humans have evolved into five different races, each of them adapted to life in different planetary conditions. Guide one of the five human factions in its exploration of the galaxy, while exploiting resources, terraforming planets and creating advanced space colonies. You may even find artifacts of a long-lost alien civilization and use them to your advantage.

A game round consists of three phases: planning phase, action phase and end of round. During the planning phase, action cards are placed face-down on any empty space of a shared planning board. When all spaces on the board have been filled, the action phase begins. In sequence, each card is revealed and all players may carry out the corresponding action. At the end of round, the action cards are returned to the players' hands and a new round begins.

The available actions are:

Production: one of the resources depicted on the card is generated on every matching planet.
Movement: starships may be moved to other planets by spending energy.
Build: colonies, factories, starships and terraformers may be built on the planets by using resource cards.
Trade: resource cards may be traded among the players and the bank.
Scoring: the players are scored based on one of the game elements depicted on the card.




The owner of each card has an advantage when resolving it, such as deciding which resource is generated or on which game element the players score.

The game ends when one player reaches at least 50 victory points or when all planets have been discovered. At that point, the player with the most victory points is the winner.
38343.name: Ad Astra

38344.name: TEE-RIVIA
38344.description:
TEE-RIVIA

Golf Trivia Game

(c)1994 DSH Enterprises

"A game for those who love golf, its rich history and its colorful heroes."

Players compete as individuals or teams as they move around a game board representing an 18 hole golf course answering trivia questions about golfing.

Includes 1200 questions on 400 cards, 6 playing pieces, dice, rules, and board.

Ages 14 and up.

38345.name: Take it Away
38345.description:
Take it Away was published in A Gamut of Games. A word by Sid Sackson:
"Take it Away is the name of the game and not, I hope, the verdict of the reader. Compared to Focus and Network, which demand extreme concentration to be played at the highest level, Take it Away can, and should, be played in a relaxed manner."

Take if away is based on Solitaire but is designed for up to four players. It uses a checkers board and poker chips in different colors. The first player take the first chip and creates a hole in the board, then the play continues with each player doing a solitaire-like move. Each chip captured counts to that player score, different colors have different values.

Any player can give-up playing at any time, except the last, that must continue play until no more moves are allowed. This last player has a penalty to his score based the chips remaining on the board.

38346.name: Hold that Line
38346.description:
Hold that Line was published in A Gamut of Games, a word by Sid Sackson:
"If all people who played Tic-Tac-Toe were laid end to end they would promptly fall asleep. That's is the kind of game it is. Yet put two people together with a pencil, a scrap of paper, and some time to kill and chances are they'll wind up playing endless games of Tic-Tac-Toe, with never a winner.
"Hold that Line is a game I devised to fill just such an odd moment. It, too, is played with a pencil and a scrap of paper, but there is a chalange and a winner in each and every game."

This game is played in a dotted grid similar to that of Dots and Dashes, but the objective is not to control boxes inside the grid, but to not be the last player drawing a line in the grid. Each line must be straigh and each player must play on either end of the line draw. The entire line must be continuous, without branches, crossings or a dot being visited twice.

38347.name: Cutting Corners
38347.description:
Cutting Corners was published in A Gamut of Games.

On a piece of paper, draw a square with two adjacent sides one color, and the other two sides the other. Each player will use a color. In your turn, a player draws a line that starts in one side of the square, do a right angle, and end in another side of the square. The first player start by doing this without further inplications, then the second player must cross one line already in the square, then next play must cross two lines, three lines, four lines and finally five lines, after that the game end with the original square divided in various sections. Each sections is won by the player that was more sides in it. Winner is the player who takes most sections.

38348.name: Paper Boxing
38348.description:
Paper Boxing was published in A Gamut of Games.

Paper Boxing simulates a boxing fight with a grid of 4x4 squares and numbers. Each player makes his grids with an S (for START) in the upper left square and completes with numbers from 1 to 15 the others in any way he wishes and in secret. Then they both reveal their grids and the first player, from the S, moves to any other adjacent square in his grid. The other player does the same. Whoever ends in the highest number won the round. Play continues like this and if the numbers are the same, the two players have a tie. If one of the players is left without moves before he can move the entire grid, he loses by KO. The player who won the most rounds wins the game.

38349.name: Last Word
38349.description:
Last Word was published in A Gamut of Games, a word by Sid Sackson
"Last Word was born one day when I was stranded with two word-game lovers far from any letter cards, letter dice, or letter tiles. Challenged, I devised a game using only an available pencil and some sheets of paper. I was rather surprised when it gained a considerable measure of popularity among my friends, some praing it as the "last word" in word games."

Last Word is played in a grid on squares 9 x 9. The central 9 squares are filled with 9 letters at random. In his turn, each player puts a new letter adjacent to at least two others already in the layout. Using this letter and the others that are in line with it, the player forms words. The letters can be rearranged in the layout to acomplish this. He can not put a letter if he can not form a word in at least two different direction and he scores by multiplying the lenght of all words formed by that letter. It is not necessary to use all letters in a direction, but all letters used must be continuous up to the letter added.

The game ends when all four edges of the grid are reached with at least one letter.

38350.name: Property
38350.description:
Property was published in A Gamut of Games.

This game is played with an 8x8 squares grid and a deck of common cards. Also, each player have some money at his disposal.

The cards are divided, being the numbers used to determine coordinates (black are the lines and red the columns)on the grid and the figures to represent buying power of the players.

In his turn, a player plays two cards corresponding to a coordinate in the grid. If that square is empty, he take possession of it, if that square belongs to another player, he must pay a rent to that player, and after that, has a chance to buy that square with his figures cards. If the square is him own, he mortgage that square. If a square is mortgaged twice, that player loses its possession.

Game ends when a player can not pay a rent. The winner is the player with most money, properties are not considered.

38351.name: Change Change
38351.description:
Change Change was published in A Gamut of Games.

In this solitaire game, the player takes eleven coins being four from two different denominations each, two from a third denomination and one different. They are arranged randomly in a 3x4 layout, with an empty space in the bottom-right.

The player aims to transform the layout into one that is symmetrical around the horizontal axis by sliding the coins (like a slide puzzle), counting each slide as a 'move'. The usual target is to complete 7 rounds in less than 100 moves.

38352.name: The No Game
38352.description:
The No Game was published in A Gamut of Games, a word by Sid Sackson:
"As promissed, here is The No Game. This is not one that I created myself, thought I wish I had. It is a great party game, taking fifteen minutes to prepare, one minute to explain, and as much time to play as the guests wish to devote to it."

It is a very simple party game in wich each player receives a ribbon. When a player makes another to say 'No', he can take all ribbons from that player. The game continues until a pre determined time, when the player with the most ribbons is declared the winner.

Play is as follows:


Locate a nice prize.
As everyone enters the party, pin a small ribbon on their clothes, one per person.
After everyone has arrived, gather them together and give a speech similar to the following:
“The object of tonight’s game is to collect the most ribbons. To collect ribbons, you must have an opponent say the word ‘No’ to you. Upon uttering that word, you may promptly collect every ribbon currently pinned on them; they are yours, at least until you say ‘No.’ Other words, phrases, and actions, like ‘Nah,’ ‘Certainly not,’ and a swift slap, are perfectly valid; only uttering the word ‘No’ causes a lack of ribbons. At [some time here], the person with the most ribbons wins the game, and receives a nice prize.”

Play as the speech above states.

38353.name: Monopol: Sverige
38353.description:
Like original monopoly, but this time with towns and pictures from Sweden.

The towns in the game are: Umeå, Skellefteå, Arvidsjaur, Vinslöv, Kiruna, Hammarstrand, Mariestad, Stockholm, Örnsköldsvik, Växjö, Piteå, Sundsvall, Göteborg, Falkenberg, Östersund, Vaggeryd, Karlskrona, Vilhelmina, Kungälv, Östmark, Visby, Luleå.

The 6 pieces looks like: skateboard, airplane, formula-1-car, nut, cellphone, inlineshoe.

Contains:
1 board
6 pieces
28 "towncards"
16 ?-cards
Monopoly-money
32 green houses
16 red houses
2 dices
Rules

38354.name: The Simpsons Board Game
38354.description:
The object of the game is to win!

Winning the game varies depending on which character you are playing.

If you are Homer, you win the game by saving enough money, 750 Bucks, to buy a new (well, nearly new) Cadillac Convertible. Then you must get back home by an exact dice roll.

If you are Marge, you win the game by saving enough money, 750 Bucks, to afford a day in health and beauty farm including hairdo, beauty make-over and manicure. Then you must get back home by an exact dice roll.

If you are Lisa, you win the game by saving enough money, 750 Bucks, to buy a real pony. Then you must get back home by an exact dice roll.

If you are Bart, you win the game by saving enough money, 750 Bucks, to buy a giant Krusty the Clown Robot, a Radioactive Man, skateboard, a deluxe catapult, a spy camera, a jiffy squirt ring, a Space Mutant Video Game, anty-gravity boots and a real tatto. Then you must get back home by an exact dice roll.

38355.name: Scene It? Star Trek
38355.description:
From the Publisher:

From the second you load the game disc into your DVD player, you'll boldly go where no Star Trek fan has gone before. From The Menagerie to The Final Conflict, Scene It? Deluxe Star Trek Edition has it all. Real television and movie clips, trivia questions and a galaxy bursting with on-screen puzzlers will test whether you need to log a few more stardates at Star Fleet Academy or you're ready to face the Final Frontier!

The game has been released in three versions: a regular Boxed Edition and two Deluxe "collector tin" Editions--SHIPS and CAPTAINS (depending on what's pictured on the cover).

The Boxed Edition Game includes:
* 1 DVD
* 1 Flextime® Game Board
* 1 Six-Sided Numbered Die
* 1 Eight-Sided Category Die
* 4 Plastic Movers (the Enterprise 1701, the Enterprise-D, the Defiant & the Voyager)
* 10 Prime Directive Cards
* 144 Trivia Cards
* 4 Category Reference Cards
* 1 Instruction Sheet

Both Deluxe Edition Games differ as follows:
* The "Movers" are now "4 Collectible Metal Tokens" (same ships as Boxed Edition)
* 16 Prime Directive Cards instead of 10
* 175 Trivia Cards instead of 144
All the other game components are identical to their Boxed Edition counterparts.
